ğŸ¦„ I survived the hackathon, caught up on sleep (mostly), and the AI debate? Still going strongâ€”at least in my head. If my last posts seemed like a soapbox, letâ€™s try a new approach. This isnâ€™t just for the devs or the writersâ€”itâ€™s anyone online trying to build, break, or create something honest.

Background (because the story matters) âœï¸

Hereâ€™s what gets me: people still treat all AI content the sameâ€”whether itâ€™s auto-generated fluff or a post like this, with actual thought, stubbornness, and a few creative detours baked in. I use AI as a tool, but Iâ€™m the one steering; itâ€™s got my fingerprints and my voice all over it because I wrote intentional AI instructions.

ğŸ™„ At least, unless GPT-5 has decided to rewrite the rules again. Then it takes a bit of wrangling first.

The sad part? Both the creative writing and the fluff get the same knee-jerk reaction. Iâ€™m not worried about myselfâ€”I know how to handle criticism and donâ€™t mind being upfront. But not everyoneâ€™s ready to jump into the ring, and a lot of good AI assisted work gets buried because creators just donâ€™t want to deal with the drama that comes with disclosure.

Hang out in the writers+AI corners of the internet for five minutes and youâ€™ll hear: â€œJust donâ€™t discloseâ€”why invite the hassle?â€ Thatâ€™s not me. Iâ€™d rather own it, even if it means the occasional argument.

ğŸ¥Š Integrity first, sparring match secondâ€”and my matches usually come with a grin and a little happy dance.

So letâ€™s walk through what we actually know about AI, what weâ€™re still sorting out, and how we might just learn to disagree without burning the place down before it's sorted. ğŸ”¥ğŸ‘©â€ğŸš’

1. Whoâ€™s Really at the Table? ğŸ—ï¸

Platforms, publishers, workplaces, classrooms, and every Discord mod with a badge gets to set their own boundaries. But the thing that always gets me isnâ€™t if they do it, itâ€™s how. When â€˜boundariesâ€™ become a one-size-fits-all firewall, thatâ€™s where I have a problem.

For example: KoFiâ€™s Discord rules are directâ€”

â€œAll forms of AI-generated content (eg. art/music/writing/ChatGPT), including links to such content, and discussion thereof is not allowed in this server.â€

So, of course, I checked. â€œDoes that mean my stuff is banned?â€ Turns out, nope. As long as I skip the preview images, weâ€™re golden. Honest, straightforward, no drama. Awesome.

Medium, though? (If you missed the post, catch up here.) They talked about gray areas... then built a giant penalty box for every AI-assisted creator, regardless of intent or craft.

ğŸµ For me, thatâ€™s about as thoughtful as banning all musicians because someone played Wonderwall one too many times at open mic night.

I canâ€™t rewrite the rulebook, but I can refuse to act like these blanket rules donâ€™t erase good, thoughtful people. Those of us who are trying to follow guidelines that don't really existâ€”and perhaps set a few new ones in the processâ€”don't deserve to have our work lumped together with the slop.

2. AI Content â‰  Equal ğŸ¥š

Thereâ€™s AI content, and then thereâ€™s AI content. Some of it is shallow, spammy filler that's cranked out for clicks with zero thought or care. The rest of us? Itâ€™s a tool wielded well: organized, rewritten, and given a real voice.

Bad actors werenâ€™t invented along with AI; the existing ones just found a different shortcut.

There are tools out thereâ€”ZeroGPT and friendsâ€”that claim theyâ€™ll catch every AI post. But hereâ€™s the thing: Iâ€™ve actually tested this. I picked three or four posts at random, ran them through different detectors, and my highest score was 18%.

ğŸ¦„ Itâ€™s not because Iâ€™m hiding anything or using some secret hack. Itâ€™s the process.

I dictate most posts on the fly. Then I hand it off to the AIâ€”to organize, to reword, sometimes to rewrite completelyâ€”but always under my set of rules. And it never, ever ends as a copy-paste job. Iâ€™m editing the whole time. Thereâ€™s always a humanâ€”meâ€”in the loop, every single time.

3. Will AI Improve Productivity? ğŸƒâ€â™€ï¸

Sometimes. Sometimes Not.

Thereâ€™s always a promise: AI will make you ten times faster, smarter, better, insert-your-buzzword-here. And maybe itâ€™s true... sometimes. Documentation? Absolutely. I can roll out a draft in secondsâ€”clean, organized, done. Drafting proposals? Donâ€™t even get me started; Iâ€™m pretty sure the principals are getting sick of how fast I can toss together a pitch.

ğŸ˜‡ If they arenâ€™t yet, give it time because I have more.

But sometimes AI just saves you from the jobs nobody wants. Like, digging through a decadeâ€™s worth of legacy code for a spike because itâ€™s finally time to rebuild that app and nobody remembers what it's actually doing or why it was even there to begin with.

ğŸ«¤ I know I donâ€™t want to do that. You donâ€™t want to do that. Nobody wants to do that. AI doesn't care and is pretty good at it!

Honestly, sometimes it sees connections I might miss. But that doesnâ€™t mean you can skip the whole process and trust whatever it finds. You still have to check. Maybe it saves you three days in the depths of the code mines, but the human review isnâ€™t optional.

Still, not every job should go to the bots, either. That gnarly production bug, that support ticket, the customer callâ€”they all need a human. AI can be a superpower, but itâ€™s not meant to replace the parts of your work that need actual judgment, empathy, or the magic of figuring it out together.

4. AI Is Not Bad (When You Use It Like a Pro) ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸš€

AI isnâ€™t some villain lurking in your workflow. Itâ€™s a force multiplier. Used right, it makes your voice sharper and your edits fasterâ€”used wrong, it just adds to the noise.

Thatâ€™s why every single commit I make defines exactly how much AI was involved and my posts are going to start wearing an â€œAI-Editedâ€ badge. Not because someone told me to. Not as a disclaimer. Because somebody has to be willing to say there's a difference between generated and assisted.

This is one version (and yesâ€”Leonardo made them):

ğŸ¦„ And if you want to use the badge yourself, or hand it off to a friend? Donâ€™t copy this little screenshotâ€”the full one (plus a couple others) are hanging out in my repo. Help yourself!

5. AI Code Is AI Content (Writers, You Too!) ğŸ’¾

Hereâ€™s my rule: disclosure, plain and simple:

  • Docs and posts: Add a simple footer like â€œThis was generated with the help of AI tool.â€
  • Code or technical writing: Commit with one of 3 different footers in the commit message:
    • Generated-with: AI tool means AI did most or all of the work
    • Co-authored-by: AI tool means the content is 50/50
    • Assisted-with: AI tool means AI helped some, but not close to half

ğŸ’¡ I started out using an email address in the commits, too â€” that I thought I was making upâ€”until some random app popped up as a contributor in my repo. Not cool... ğŸ˜’

This isnâ€™t about checking boxes. Itâ€™s about giving credit, setting an example, and actually being transparent with yourself and the future people who end up needing it.

ğŸ˜ˆ Besides, putting one more stamp on a long list of responsible AI use-cases puts a dent in the endless cycle of AI panic and the-world-is-ending doom speak.

6. And What About AI Images or Music? ğŸ¨

Same rules, different paint. Some artists pour weeks or months into training models on their own art. (I still havenâ€™t managed to train mine and it's been over a month!) Others take the shortcut: punch in a sentence or two, let the AI â€œenhanceâ€ it, and call it done.

â“ Are they copying someoneâ€™s style? I dunnoâ€”maybe? Should they? I honestly donâ€™t know...

Same applies here as does with writing: artists absolutely have the right to protect their work. But what does that look like, practically? Truth is we donâ€™t really know yet. The laws are behind while the tech is still racing ahead. Weâ€™ll catch up. Maybe not soon enough, but eventually, we will.

ğŸ¦„ I just hope that when we get there, thereâ€™s at least one person in the room who actually understands whatâ€™s happeningâ€”and what it looks like behind the scenes. We absolutely need better laws, but we do not need people throwing broad rules at some conjured image of â€œAI training.â€ Whatever it ends up being, honesty and fact need to come first.

7. Is AI â€œStealingâ€? (No, but...) ğŸ§¬

This is where I dig in my heels. No, using AI-generated content is not stealingâ€”unless youâ€™re actively pretending someone elseâ€™s work is your own or ignoring copyright on purpose. However, â€œpublicly availableâ€ isnâ€™t the same as â€œpublic domain,â€ and nobody should lose credit for their work.

Should AI companies pay for certain data? Probably! Should writers and artists get a say? Of course. But â€œall AI is theftâ€ is just as over-simplified as â€œall creators are saints.â€

ğŸ«¡ Guess what? Real life and the world around us is messyâ€”AI included. We need smarter laws, better tools, and way less finger-pointing.

8. I Canâ€™t Stay Quiet (and Neither Should You) ğŸ› ï¸

I can't just sit back and watch the insanity and not throw my two cents in. Weâ€™re all still figuring this thing out. Some jumped in headfirst, others are barely dipping a toe. But we wonâ€™t get anywhere by shutting down the conversation or tuning each other outâ€”if thereâ€™s a better way, weâ€™re gonna have to find it together.

So, did I miss anything? Add your take belowâ€”whatâ€™s a rule, reality, or tip about AI you wish more people got right? Comment, DM, or write your own story. Iâ€™ll keep this list updated.

ğŸ™ And please, when it comes up again, donâ€™t leave yourself (or anyone else) out of the conversation. ğŸ«¶

ğŸ¦„ FYI: I updated this after the factâ€”I did plan two full weeks down to the minuteâ€”but I didnâ€™t plan for not having the data or not having a solid backup when it didnâ€™t arrive. Also, I lost half a day to Figmaâ€™s decorative quicksand. The rushed thing I pasted to make the buzzer didnâ€™t sound like me, so this is the version I can live with (and you can actually read for fun). ğŸª„

What I Built

Underfoot (my stubborn little ChatPot) is a chatbot that finds locals-only, off-the-map places you wonâ€™t see on Yelp or TripAdvisor. You give it a location and intent (music, coffee, hiking, spider farmsâ€¦) and it returns unique results with a Stonewalker rating. Each query also adds anonymous whispers to the cache, so the dataset grows as people use it. ğŸ¯

GitHub Repository â€” docs, flows, screenshots

Underfoot Chat â€” The Stonewalker Agent (try it)

Underfoot â€” the locals-only treasure hunter ğŸ’

I didnâ€™t try to cram this into a weekend; I mapped two weeks like a flight plan. The part that snapped first was the one I trusted too much: a data preload that was â€œreadyâ€ on paper and nowhere in reality. My beautiful schedule grew a crater where the testing window used to be, and from there it was just me, the agent, the caches, and a lot of swearing said lovingly at my own ambition. ğŸ§­

The whisper-network: project background ğŸ“¼

Late â€™90s / early 2000s Georgia, when cell phones were for emergencies and you rationed the battery like it owed you money. My brother and I chased off-the-wall spots through a whisper network: backyard mini-festivals with passwords in the backs of free magazines, odd museums, ghost tours that were either hilariously fake or so real you quietly recalibrated your cosmology on the drive home. Too public and the cops came; too secret and the field stayed empty. We loved that balance.

Underfoot bottles that energy. You give the resident Stonewalker an intent you actually feel (â€œlive music,â€ â€œodd museums,â€ â€œstrange gardens,â€ â€œspider farmâ€) plus a location. It crawls the not-obvious places first, normalizes the messy HTML, then returns a ranked list that says, â€œthis is probably your kind of weirdâ€”go now.â€ ğŸ•µï¸â€â™€ï¸

The â€œcatchâ€: sometimes these events havenâ€™t been discovered yetâ€” that's how these things work. Besides, a chatbot canâ€™t politely wait for scraping, so every {intent, location} pair sends out separate whispers that build the cache for that combo. The next personâ€™s list is a little louder and a little wilder than the last. ğŸ”

I canâ€™t do simple (and I stopped pretending otherwise) ğŸ§¶

I promise â€œtiny demo,â€ and five minutes later I have: an ADR (revised twice), a color palette in Leonardo, three caches, and a Future Enhancements page that looks like a subway map someone cried coffee onto. Itâ€™s not scope creep; itâ€™s scope pre-planning. I need to see the whole creature to ship a slice.

Vibe-coding lasted maybe two minutes. Copilot drafted the UI, I took a scenic (unnecessary) tour through Figma, flirted with Stitch, sprinted to n8n because hosted chat looked fast, missed my UI and dragged it back, and somewhere in there I wrote the agent I actually wantedâ€”decisions like a product, not a science-fair trifold. ğŸ§ª

Why I donâ€™t do hackathons (and why I did this one anyway) â±ï¸

Hackathons want a snapshot; I build ecosystems. They want â€œFriday by midnightâ€; I want to label the stations, run one line today, and the others next week. I joined anyway because this is the exact agent Iâ€™ve wanted to build for months. It was funâ€”and it reminded me why trusting a green checkbox you donâ€™t control is a dice roll. ğŸŸ©

What it looks like â€” the sprint with real nouns ğŸ§µ

Two mouths, one brain:

  • n8n Hosted Chat (discovered late, used constantly)
  • A tiny Copilot-assisted React UI once I get this deployed and working the way it does in my head. I will update with this link too.

Both funnel free-form requests into { intent, location }.

Then:

  • Fetch from the non-mainstream first (Facebook events that behave, Reddit posts that map to places or pop-ups, a growing â€œweird webâ€ list living in Obsidian).
  • Parse with minimal markup assumptions (HTML changes when you blink).
  • De-dupe with URL + fuzzy geo (and strip tracking sludge).
  • Score with the decimal Stonewalker blend: uniqueness â€¢ locality â€¢ recency â€¢ intent-fit.
  • Cache to Supabase (scraping the same planet twice is a sin).

I hit n8nâ€™s memory ceiling right when the first end-to-end run smiled at me. Reflex: vectors + RAG + tidy GCP attic. Reality: the clock. I did the boring, correct thingâ€”pull less, trim sooner, cache earlier. Two caches unlocked; the third is a miniboss Iâ€™ll beat when Iâ€™m not running on midnight. ğŸ§±

AI agents: saints on Monday, goblins on Tuesday ğŸ‘¾

Agents in the system and agents helping build the systemâ€”both truths can be true in the same hour:

  • ChatGPT yanked me out of holes, then cited docs from a neighbor universe ten minutes later.
  • Copilot went license-dark mid-sprintâ€”peak front-end day timing.
  • Leonardo kept momentum by letting me see the brand when the plumbing got gnarly.
  • Various chat boxes (n8n, Bright Data, Supabase) were great rubber ducks until they hallucinated syntax.

## What it looks like â€” the sprint with real nouns ğŸ§µ

Two mouths, one brain:
- **n8n Hosted Chat** (discovered late, used constantly)
- A tiny **Copilot-assisted React UI** once I get this deployed and working the way it does in my head. I will update with this link too.

Both funnel free-form requests into `{ intent, location }`.

Then:
- **Fetch** from the non-mainstream first (Facebook events that behave, Reddit posts that map to places or pop-ups, a growing â€œweird webâ€ list living in Obsidian).
- **Parse** with minimal markup assumptions (HTML changes when you blink).
- **De-dupe** with URL + fuzzy geo (and strip tracking sludge).
- **Score** with the decimal **Stonewalker** blend: uniqueness â€¢ locality â€¢ recency â€¢ intent-fit.
- **Cache** to **Supabase** (scraping the same planet twice is a sin).

I hit **n8nâ€™s memory ceiling** right when the first end-to-end run smiled at me. Reflex: vectors + RAG + tidy GCP attic. Reality: the clock. I did the boring, correct thingâ€”**pull less, trim sooner, cache earlier**. Two caches unlocked; the third is a miniboss Iâ€™ll beat when Iâ€™m not running on midnight. ğŸ§±

---

## AI agents: saints on Monday, goblins on Tuesday ğŸ‘¾

Agents *in* the system and agents *helping* build the systemâ€”both truths can be true in the same hour:

- **ChatGPT** yanked me out of holes, then cited docs from a neighbor universe ten minutes later.
- **Copilot** went license-dark mid-sprintâ€”peak front-end day timing.
- **Leonardo** kept momentum by letting me *see* the brand when the plumbing got gnarly.
- Various **chat boxes** (n8n, Bright Data, Supabase) were great rubber ducks until they hallucinated syntax.

**Rule that saved me:** no agent writes straight to storage. The **normalizer** is the law. Drafts can be flammable; data cannot. ğŸ§¯

---

## The cache: Sheets vs Supabase (be a database, not a vibe) ğŸ—„ï¸

I tried to keep the prototype in Google Sheets because it was there and felt simple. Simple lied. As soon as you care about de-dupe, TTLs, hit/miss tracking, and â€œplease donâ€™t melt anyoneâ€™s hobby site,â€ you need grown-up storage. I pivoted to **Supabase**, met **Row-Level Security (RLS)** and **grants** like a mini-boss in a fresh dungeon (v17 feels spicier), learned just enough to stop tripping over my new `underfoot` schema, and came out with two caches behavingâ€”and a third that now knows the sound of my footsteps. ğŸªª

---

## Underfoot belongs in your pocket (laptops were the proving ground) ğŸ“±

It runs on a computer because thatâ€™s where the tools live, but **Underfoot is meant for your phone**â€”a â€œyouâ€™re already out, whatâ€™s weird nearby?â€ companion. One-tap location, swipeable cards you can skim at a red light (responsibly), save/share that doesnâ€™t fight you, and a quiet toggle: â€œnudge me when something odd appears within five miles.â€

**Path:** **PWA now** (installable, offline last results, Share Target) â†’ **push later** (saved intents â†’ â€œnew oddities near youâ€) â†’ **Expo wrap** with haptics and deep links like `underfoot://place/:id` so maps feel native. ğŸ§­

---

## What I did wrong (say it out loud) ğŸ§¨

- **Trusted an external preload without a Plan B.** The curated 2.3M rows never landed; my testing window vanished; I rewrote for â€œfetch + cacheâ€ and paid the polish tax. ğŸ”Œ
- **Spent a half-day in Figma I couldnâ€™t spare.** Respect to UX; for me it was decorative quicksand. ğŸ¨
- **Let â€œCloudflare will be easyâ€ live rent-free.** It wasnâ€™t. Keep the UI small; add a tiny Worker proxy only where needed. â˜ï¸
- **Left Copilot tied to work.** Running out of credits mid-sprint felt like knitting with oven mitts. ğŸ§¤
- **Underestimated n8n memory.** Fixed by budgeting data like money: pull less, trim sooner, cache earlier. ğŸ§®
- **Structured output optimism.** Agents *can* do it, but the normalizer must be the bouncer from hour one. ğŸ“‡

> ğŸ¦„ I still had a blast, learned a ton, and might even do it againâ€”after a nap and a vacation from permissions dialogs. ğŸŒ™

---

## Future plans (also in the repo) ğŸ§±

**High-impact next:** dataset preload I control (seeded batches), vector search via pgvector once the pipeline is boring, Google Places (Text/Nearby + Details) through the same normalizer, and a curated â€œweird webâ€ seed list (40â€“50 URLs you wouldnâ€™t know to google, scheduled fetcher, quality scoring so the noisy ones get benched). ğŸ§°

**Cache-first response:** the Whisper Network runs in the background, but the agent should **hit the cache first**. Update the prompt/flow to enforce cache â†’ live tools.

**Cache management planning:** I put a lot of design work into how the cache could be structured to allow for future RAG-type navigation, along with simpler embeds for straight vector search. However, I put zero thought (asides from "I need to think about that at some point") into actually managing it _after_ the data is there. For now, it's all dependent on a merge that's unique by URL. 

  - That "unique" URL isn't very reliable and needs a better "smart" dedupe system
  - I took a limited hour-ish aside through the land of TTL in Google Sheets (_not at all recommended_, by the way) and learned that any way I tried to make it work it always had the same result = _terrible idea_. That's how Supabase got involved, but ultimately broke things worse than fixing them. **I probably should have left it alone.**

**Localization:** right now it returns the first geocoder result for speed. Flesh this out so results match what people *meant*, not just what a geocoder guessed.

**Experience:** transparent Stonewalker scoring you can peek and tweak; richer cards (images, tags, map snaps, save/share lists, quick filters); a quieter Discord bot that delivers value, not noise; mobile that respects thumbs and daylight. âœ¨

**Reliability:** Normalization 2.0 is the law; a tiny â€œrepairâ€ agent only when validation fails; better cross-source entity linking so â€œThe Old Millâ€ is one placeâ€”not fourteen. ğŸ”

---

### Technical Stuff

- **System Instructions:** Stonewalker persona â€” hybrid nature/tech guide with a maps + travel focus.  
- **Model:** GPT-4.1-mini (full model as backup).  
- **Memory/Cache:** normalized results for reuse (v2.0); prototype began in Google Sheets.  
- **Nodes:** HTTP Request, Function (normalize/de-dupe), Discord notifier. **Bright Data Verified** node was great when it fit; I often swapped to plain HTTP for unusual flows.  
- **Central AI agent:** *The Stonewalker.*  
  - I had a separate data-only agent; it took too long for mediocre results. After cache reliability + maps data, Iâ€™ll revisit.  
- **Triggers:** Webhook (custom UI) + n8n Chat (convenience).  
- **Sources:** internal cache (in progress), Google Maps SERP (fallback), Google SERP, Reddit, Facebook events, pre-approved secondary sources (future).  
- **Output:** structured parser + secondary normalizer.  
  - I went back and forth on structured output; docs warn against strict schemas with agents. The normalizer stays the final authority.  
- **Error handling:** Discord notifierâ€”useful, loud; needs formatting + routing love.  
- **Planned:** Bright Data Google Maps dataset *(delivered 2025-09-01 03:43 PDT â€” thanks, team).*  

---

## Screenshots ğŸ–¼ï¸

---

## Quick links ğŸ”—

**Repo:** https://github.com/CheckMarKDevTools/underfoot-underground-travel-planner

---

## ğŸ›¡ï¸ R.A.I. â€” Responsible AI (how this stays good on purpose)

- **Transparency:** model-generated text is obvious in context; ranked results cite sources; Stonewalker scores are explainable (uniqueness â€¢ locality â€¢ recency â€¢ intent-fit) with tunables coming. ğŸ”  
- **Privacy:** no PII required; anonymous intent + coarse location only; one-click â€œforget meâ€ clears local cache and server traces tied to your session. ğŸ«¥  
- **Respect:** honor `robots.txt`, rate limits, and site TOS; prefer official APIs; link back, donâ€™t lift; no paywalls or wholesale republishing. ğŸ§‘â€âš–ï¸  
- **Safety:** filter obviously harmful/illegal content and adult venues by default; opt-in gates for edgier categories; down-rank chains; spotlight genuinely local listings. ğŸ§¯  
- **Hallucination guard:** agents donâ€™t write to storage; a deterministic normalizer validates/repairs/rejects before anything lands; uncertainty is surfaced in the UI. ğŸ§ª  
- **Security:** secrets live server-side; least-privilege keys; redacted logs; regular rotation. ğŸ›¡ï¸  
- **Crawl with manners:** staggered schedules, backoff, polite concurrency so nobodyâ€™s hobby site gets melted. ğŸ¢  

> ğŸ¦„ **Confession:** Yes I cheated â€” I let ChatGPT write the initial submission, which honestly I didn't even have time to read. There is no telling what was on it, but I know it _wasn't mine_ and it was making me crazy. ğŸ¤ª So please, **do not judge this writing** as part of whatever scoring happens with the project. It was all done _after_ the deadline.
>

## Epilogue ğŸ“

Half of what I attempted was a bad ideaâ€”which is why I deferred the other half on purposeâ€”and somehow I still had the best time. Iâ€™m tired in the satisfying way. I want a nap *and* I want to open my phone in a random city and hear Stonewalker whisper â€œturn left.â€ Thatâ€™s how I know Iâ€™m not doneâ€”just paused long enough to tell you what really happened. ğŸŒ†

---

## ğŸ§ ğŸ’¥ The Oomph (mic-drop)

The clock ran out; the curiosity didnâ€™t. **Underfoot / Stonewalker** already finds the odd little places that make a town feel alive, and the desk was just a proving ground because **your pocket is the point**â€”one tap, one intent, a handful of cards that feel like a friend leaning in to whisper, *psst, go here*. ğŸŒ™

title: The Hackathon I Swore Off â€” and the Exhaustion That Mostly Compiled
content_html:
ğŸ¦„ I know today is technically Copilot day, but honestly? I don't have space for another technical thought in my head right now. In case you missed it, I decided on a whim to submit a project in the n8n/BrightData hackathon.

By itself, it's not saying much. But lifting a 10-year self-imposed hackathon ban is not a light thing for somebody whose version of all-in means every last ounce of everything I had was put into that one project over those two weeks.

So instead of technical today, I've decided it's story time ğŸ˜‡ Welcome to my only slightly dramatized retelling of true events. I'll explain why I don't do hackathons plus the thing that ultimately changed my mind.

So, pull up a chair. Iâ€™ll start at the beginning of the end. ğŸª‘ğŸ¢

Baby Bottles and Fry Baskets ğŸ‘¶ğŸ”

In 2008, my son was born. That was the time warp. Just a jump to the left, a step to the right, and suddenly my life wasnâ€™t mine anymore.

ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’« Parenthood is the only true overnight shift. One day youâ€™re yourself, the next youâ€™re permanently on call for a 7lb CEO who screams about everything.

At that point I was still sticking it out in restaurants â€” where I'd been for close to ten years. It was long hours, long drives, and I had very little to show for it.

By January 2011, I was running on fumes and sheer force of will. Then the snowstorm hit. Everything was frozen, and there I was, alone, opening the restaurant. I ran the whole place myself: front line, back line, fry station, drive-thru, you-name-it.

ğŸ¦„ "Can't" has never been in my vocabulary. By all accounts I should have stayed home that day, but I wasn't about to let a little ice stop me from doing my job. The fact that I was alone was beyond my control. So I did what I knew to do, in any way I could make it happen.

People were waiting at least thirty minutes, minimum, because one person can only move so fast, but the line just kept coming. At some point in the middle of that non-stop chaos, I looked up and saw my drive-thru customers standing inside.

ğŸš¦ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸ Guess theyâ€™d been stuck out there long enough because before I knew what happened, a small group had collected in the lobby watching me sprint around like it was a personal comedy show.

In the moment, we made the best of it. We laughed, we joked, and I ran my ass off. Restaurants arenâ€™t designed to run solo, but I made it work.

That day I remember clearly â€” the day the rest of the world was shut down and I realized the joke was on me. There I was running a one-woman circus while everyone else got to stay home.

I asked myself one question: What exactly are you doing here?

A few months later, I finally walked away, for good.

The Student Loan Circus ğŸ“ğŸ’¸

That summer, I went back to school. Student loans as the only source of income â€” my lifeline. Most days, daycare covered things. Some days it didnâ€™t.

And there I was: the older student dragging a kid into class, existing in a universe completely separate from everyone else.

ğŸ‘Ÿ Their concerns were about parties and weekend plans. Mine were homework checks, missing shoes, and bills that didnâ€™t pay themselves.

That was the dichotomy of my reality back then. My life just didn't fit into their box. But by junior or senior year, Iâ€™d settled into a rhythm.

Then came the group project.

The monster assignment. Sixty percent of the final grade hanging over all of us. The professorâ€™s grand strategy? Hands up, step back, â€œdo your thing.â€ Great...

ğŸ¦„ Seriously, it was chaos dressed up as independence. Pick your projects, pick your teams, no submissions accepted after the deadline for any reason. I should have known hope was limited at that point.

Thatâ€™s when I suddenly became popular. The same people whoâ€™d barely looked my way all semester were now lining up to hitch their wagon to my grade. And of course, they wanted me to lead. Leadership wasnâ€™t an issue â€” Iâ€™d been doing that for years.

ğŸ¤¨ So yâ€™all want me in charge? Fine. But here are the ground rules: Iâ€™m not guessing, weâ€™re not bouncing dates around, and certain nights are simply not happening. We meet weekly. We get it done. We move on. Period.

Everyone nodded, even the professor (who I involved early on just in case things went sideways) gave me the â€œsounds goodâ€ approval. For a moment, I actually thought we had a workable agreement. I was wrong.

What followed was six weeks of circus hell. I brought calendars, agendas, timelines. They brought excuses. Too busy. Wrong night. Maybe later.

ğŸ˜– I've never been so amazed at people claiming to work! They shuffled meetings around like rearranging the board was the same thing as playing the game. And then acted like they deserved extra credit for their trouble.

Meanwhile, my reality lived in another universe: making sure homework got done, hunting down missing shoes, figuring out dinner on nights when the loans had already run dry.

The gap between what they thought mattered and what I was actually carrying was ludicrous.

ğŸ¤¯ To this day, I still donâ€™t know what half of them were even trying to say. All I knew was project due and kid at home. Anything beyond that simply didn't factor into the equation.

The Kicker ğŸ’¥

When I thought maybe I could finally breathe, the peer reviews landed:

  • Failure to communicate. Really? I had a plan mapped out since day one. Emails and group texts were constantly ignored, but somehow that's my fault?
  • Doesnâ€™t work well with teams. Teams that donâ€™t show up arenâ€™t teams. At that point itâ€™s just me, and if itâ€™s me, I get it done. Thatâ€™s the whole story.
  • Canâ€™t handle pressure. My favorite.

ğŸ”¥ You want pressure? Iâ€™ll let you babysit my kid, pay my bills, worry about classes and day care, and then weâ€™ll talk about pressure.

The fact that your last-minute date took you away from the project? Thatâ€™s not pressure. Thatâ€™s stupidity and not my problem.

I was livid. The immaturity was staggering. This was not the class I thought Iâ€™d signed up for. So I marched back to the professor â€” the same one whoâ€™d nodded at my ground rules like they were gospel â€” expecting backup.

Instead, I got a â€œsolution.â€ Maybe, he suggested, I should try a group activity. ğŸ¤¯ğŸ˜±ğŸ¤¬

Translation: hackathon.

The Hackathon I Swore Off ğŸ•ğŸ’»

A hackathon? Because obviously the cure for dealing with people who never show up is to lock me in a room with them for forty-eight hours straight. Brilliant.

But this wasnâ€™t optional. Those peer reviews werenâ€™t just comments, they were baked into the grade. My arguments didnâ€™t matter.

ğŸ˜‘ Agree or not, I had to make up for the fact that my so-called â€œteamâ€ â€” that useless cluster of hangers-on and deadweights â€” had once again barged into my life and left me holding the bag.

And the price this time was a whole weekend I didnâ€™t have to spare.

So I did it. Two days in the lab, stale pizza boxes stacked like trophies, Mountain Dew flowing like tap water. The twenty-year-olds bounced around as if sleep was optional, while I was counting babysitting hours like poker chips and wondering how many cups of coffee equal a nap.

ğŸŒªï¸ It was sheer chaos, and not the good kind.

I got to know people, sure, maybe even understood them a little better. But I was exhausted and my price was sitting at home without me while I watched people bluff their way through the night.

By the end I could barely remember my own name. And I walked out swearing: never again. Not unless I could give it one hundred percent â€” which I knew I couldnâ€™t, not while a six-year-old still needed me every moment of every day.

Until Now ğŸ”„â³

Fast-forward to 2025. My sonâ€™s grown, living with his dad, and for the first time in nearly twenty years, I have time that actually belongs to me. Then along comes this challenge: n8n, agents, scrapers â€” basically my bucket list wrapped in one neat little package.

So I broke my rule. WakaTime says I spent more than a hundred hours in two weeks, and that doesnâ€™t even count the black hole of time lost to the n8n UI â€” or my day job that doesnâ€™t allow time off for my randomness (no matter how forgiving they are of my standups). Nights bled into four-thirty in the morning. Work still started at nine. Weekends turned into catch-up lies I told myself to feel better.

ğŸ¨ I coded until my brain short-circuited, then wandered off to Leonardo to play with color because apparently sleep deprivation makes me an artist.

Thatâ€™s the thing about hackathons: they chew you up. The clock never stops, and youâ€™re not polishing anything â€” itâ€™s MVP or bust. The urge to overbuild doesnâ€™t go away, but the deadline keeps you honest.

And the prize money? Forget it. If thatâ€™s your motivation, just get a job. At least those checks clear. The real payoff is the exhaustion you somehow enjoy, the kind where you know you emptied the tank and came out standing anyway.

ğŸ«© So yeah, Iâ€™m wrecked and my brain owes me four days of sleep.

But unlike that overnight hackathon years ago, I didnâ€™t walk away muttering â€œnever again.â€ This time I realized Iâ€™d come full circle. Back then, the rule was survival. With a kid, student loans, and no margin for error, I couldnâ€™t afford to burn myself out for fun.

Now, I finally could. And it turns out I didnâ€™t just survive it â€” I loved it. ğŸ’Ÿ

When Survival Turns Into Choice ğŸ§­

And maybe thatâ€™s the truth hiding in all of this: â€œnever againâ€ usually just means â€œnot right now.â€

Itâ€™s okay to slam the door shut, to swear something off loudly enough that everyone hears you â€” sometimes thatâ€™s survival. But donâ€™t be surprised when the same thing comes knocking again years later.

And who knows? Maybe the next time it shows up, it brings something a little different with it. ğŸ«¶

Ashley Childress

Distributed backend specialist. Perfectly happy playing second fiddleâ€”it means I get to chase fun ideas, dodge meetings, and break things no one told me to touch, all without anyone questioning it. ğŸ˜‡

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Responsible AI Statement (RAI)

This post was drafted with the assistance of AI. The memories, chaos, and full-circle exhaustion are mine. The words were built together in the style you just read.

So, I'm yelling, "that's definitely not my face!" and ChatGPT insists theres a resemblance (there's not). It didn't take much for me to give up and upload a real picture, as a guide.

ğŸ¦„ Spoiler: The very next one was a total disaster, but the last attempt? Not half bad! ğŸ¤£

Iâ€™m pretty positive that I donâ€™t have a single post with the sort of footer/disclaimer that Iâ€™ve been preaching about for weeks, to anyone who would listen to me. ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸

GitHub Copilot

Iâ€™ll share what partâ€™s have actually been working at some point, but so far the answer is "not a lot".

Codex

ğŸ¦„ Donâ€™t worry, Iâ€™m sure the obsession will wear off eventually... maybe... oh hell, probably not. Never mind! ğŸ˜…

  • Gimp isnâ€™t AI, but it's my go-to for anything image related.   • Scan the entire post and make changes wherever needed to remove unintentional bias, and for every change you make, summarize it with examples and show me why your version is better suited.

Iâ€™m getting better as we go, but itâ€™s really just a safety net so I donâ€™t accidentally put my foot in my mouth after taking the scenic route to my point (itâ€™s a talent). ğŸ“¸

  • Keep my original attitude and quirks as much as possible, but not to the extent that it contradicts the first point.

I really donâ€™t have a better word for what happens during this phase, because thatâ€™s exactly what it feels like. ChatGPT took my nice story and turned it into something that I only vaguely recognize, so Iâ€™ll argue that itâ€™s TOO changed.

This is where the content of the blog conversation in ChatGPT pivots and Iâ€™ll have it show me a random 10 emojis that could work for a particular phrase or scenario - Iâ€™ll pick from there. Same with section titles and quotes, too.

ğŸ’¿ When it comes to titles, quotes, and references - it's rarely as simple as picking one from a list. Most of the time, I'll pick parts of at least three and then feed them back to ChatGPT to make coherent again.

At this point itâ€™s all loaded into Dev, but I'm still reviewing repeatedly until I can make it from top to bottom without the urge to change something immediately (which can sometimes take a couple days - like this post âš¡ï¸).

Thereâ€™s typically a whole lot of page swapping (preview > edit > preview) until Iâ€™m finally happy with the overall version. From there, most posts get scheduled for Wednesday mornings.

ğŸª´ Why? No reason, really - itâ€™s more random chance. Iâ€™ve tried to stay on at least a weekly schedule since I joined. If I schedule the big posts, I know I wonâ€™t accidentally miss a day. ğŸ˜‡

SEVEN. Update: RAI Footer

So hereâ€™s a late-breaking update: After I stumbled onto a post over on Medium (for reasons I still canâ€™t fully explain ğŸ™„), I decided to forward some of these posts there too. Turns out, Medium has a whole policy on â€œAI-generatedâ€ content â€” because of course they do. And since I can never resist at a good debate, letâ€™s be extra clear about how these work.

Those â€œRAI Footersâ€ you see at the end of each post? Theyâ€™re mostly the work of ChatGPT now, spun up from my own pile of instructions.

The usual ask:
Take the main theme of this post and add a unique, fun way to say that you (the AI) helped make it happen.

I always review and edit for good measure, but honestly, after ChatGPT does all the heavy lifting, itâ€™s only fair it gets its own section. This is the AI-generated section, after all. Seems only right to give the robot its moment in the spotlight. ğŸ©

TL;DR: The Heart of the Matter ğŸ«€

If youâ€™ve made it this far, now you know:

  • Yes, I use AI - a LOT
  • No, it doesnâ€™t do all the work for me
  • Yes, I argue with it (and sometimes lose...)
  • No, it hasnâ€™t taken over my personality
  • Yes, the cover art is AI-generated
    • unless itâ€™s truly hideous - those are locked in the vault!

The real secret is that all of this is still me! Iâ€™m just occasionally powered up by caffeine and robots. â˜•ï¸ğŸ¤–

Chime In ğŸ¤

Got tips, tricks, or your own tales of AI chaos? Iâ€™d love to hear from you - add your two cents below!

ğŸ›¡ï¸ I Used AI, But Blame Me

Everything I share here is my own perspective - created with the help of AI tools (GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT, and their friends), but always with a human (me) in the loop. I do my best to catch accidental bias and fact-check, but if you ever spot something odd, let me know! AI isnâ€™t perfect, and neither am I.

If youâ€™ve made it this far, now you know:

- No, it doesnâ€™t do _all_ the work for me

> The real secret is that all of this is _still me_! Iâ€™m just occasionally powered up by caffeine and robots. â˜•ï¸ğŸ¤–

Got tips, tricks, or your own tales of AI chaos? Iâ€™d love to hear from you - add your two cents below!

content_html:
Confession âœ¨

I almost pulled the Procrastination card on this one. ğŸ¤ Turns out, I probably skipped ahead in the Copilot-prompting Olympics, forgetting some folks are still stretching at the starting line. But I also promised one more round, and thereâ€™s still way too much I havenâ€™t shared.

So, hereâ€™s the plan ğŸ§­: This post is a bit of a sampler platter â€” perfect for anyone tinkering with GitHub Copilot, whether youâ€™re just getting started or youâ€™re already deep into prompt experimentation. Maybe youâ€™ve been following along and something still feels a little off, or maybe you found this post while hunting for new tricks to unlock a work project (or nudge your personal bucket list a little closer to â€œdoneâ€). No matter how you landed here, thereâ€™s something for you.

If youâ€™re not there yet â€” donâ€™t worry! Just give it a try, see what happens, and check back next week for a completely new (and much less terrifying) approach. I'm always cooking up new ideas or finding inventive ways to break old ones ğŸ˜‡

Quick Refresher â€” PRIOR Prompting

If you just landed here, start with Part 1 (seriously â€” itâ€™ll make this way less confusing). Not for my views, but because everything here builds on earlier concepts. If youâ€™re up to speed, speed read the refresher and dive right in!

The PRIOR System for Reusable Prompts ğŸª„

Hereâ€™s my not-so-secret sauce for writing prompts that actually work:

  1. Persona â€“ Give Copilot a role to play (the weirder, the better)
  2. Requirements â€“ What does â€œdoneâ€ look like? Be crystal clear.
  3. Impediments â€“ Constraints that keep Copilot out of the ditch.
  4. Output â€“ How and what you want returned. Structure = repeatable.
  5. Reference Examples â€“ Real, honest-to-goodness examples, both wins and fails.

ğŸ¦„ Yes, I made it up. And yes, it works! If you manage to break it, message me for a virtual coffee and a gold star. â˜•ï¸ğŸŒŸ
Creativity welcome, but shenanigans encouraged!

Start Fresh, Then Optimize ğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸

If youâ€™ve gone through all the PRIOR steps and Copilot is still giving you answers that feel...off (â€œI said blue sky â€” that is a sky, but why is it purple?â€), donâ€™t panic! Before you go on a prompt-fixing spree, try these quick checks first:

Truth bomb: 99% of Copilot â€œfailuresâ€ are just crummy (or missing) repo instructions. Donâ€™t believe me? Treat it like the â€œCopilot Easter Egg Huntâ€: if you run into a prompt problem you genuinely canâ€™t solve, drop it in the comments. If you actually stump me, youâ€™ll get full bragging rights â€” and Iâ€™ll spotlight your curveball (and, if I crack it, share the fix) in a future post. Nine times out of ten, though? Tweak your instructions and the problem disappears.

Stuck? Try These Quick Fixes ğŸª¤

  1. Check Your Input: Is your question actually clear? Would your past self, or a random teammate, know exactly what you mean? If not, rewrite your ask with a little more context or supply explicit examples.

  2. Ask Copilot to Explain: Use Copilotâ€™s â€œexplain this codeâ€ or similar command on your prompt, not your code. What does it think you want? If itâ€™s wildly off, break it down into smaller sections and review each one at a time.

  3. Review Repo Instructions: Open your .github/copilot-instructions.md file and just read it out loud. Does it make sense, or does it sound like a jumbled set of copy-paste rules? Most issues start here!

  4. Start With Defaults: Temporarily comment out all your custom instructions and use a â€œvanillaâ€ Copilot prompt. Is the result better, worse, or just... different? This is a simple way to isolate and test if your changes are helping or hurting. Slowly add one at a time back, and send multiple prompts in between.

  5. Prompt-Within-a-Prompt: Ask Copilot, â€œWhat instructions are you following right now?â€ or â€œHow would you summarize your task?â€ Sometimes the AI will spill its logic, letting you spot mismatches you never expected.

  6. Screenshot the Weird: Save any oddball results Copilot gives you. Patterns usually emerge â€” especially when you look back at several examples.

If you take my system, remix it, and invent a prompt thatâ€™s even better â€” share it with the group (me!) What worked for you or failed when you least expected it?

Real-world Example ğŸ«¥

A few weeks ago, I was building out reusable parts for conventional commit prompts. Theyâ€™d worked fine across several projects â€” until I broke them out into separate modules. Suddenly, Copilot switched from helpful answers to just summarizing its entire conversation history, no matter what I asked. ğŸ˜¡ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

So I went back to basics, commenting out nearly everything in the prompt and adding back small sections one at a time. Eventually, I found the culprit: a single instruction forcing Copilot to re-read its whole history, flooding the context window and making it summarize the past instead of the changes. ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«

Even after finding the strange trigger, I didnâ€™t really understand why it broke things. Cue ChatGPTâ€™s helpful â€œexplain like Iâ€™m fiveâ€ walkthrough of what was happening behind the scenes (later confirmed with Copilotâ€™s debug logs). Once I removed that one line, everything worked like normal again. ğŸŒˆ

And thatâ€™s the real lesson: Copilot â€” or any AI assistant â€” is just another tool in your toolbox. When it starts acting up or giving weird results, donâ€™t panic. Debug it the same way youâ€™d debug any stubborn code or logic bug: one step at a time. ğŸ˜‰

Meta-Optimize Your Prompts ğŸ¤–ğŸ¤ğŸ¤–

Still not satisfied? Hereâ€™s where you really level up â€” try this: paste your prompt into ChatGPT and ask it to review and suggest improvements. Even better, try giving ChatGPT the role of Merge Goblin and see what it does with your own instructions.

Seriously, I do this all the time! I pasted the original Merge Goblin example into an untrained GPT chat with something like this:

How would you interpret these instructions if you were Copilot? Spot any places where these instructions could be misunderstood or improved. Output a bulleted list of suggested improvements.

I got suggestions like:

  • Clarify input handling (summaries, code, chaosâ€”Merge Goblin will handle it)
  • Make emoji and format rules ironclad
  • Keep clarifying questions brief and goblin-y
  • Ban all meta-phrases and markdown

ğŸ¥· Steal what works. Ignore what doesnâ€™t. Bonus points if you out-weird me with your improvements!

Structure with XML-Style (Fake) Tags ğŸ—‚ï¸

AI loves order and structure is magic. ğŸ§š I started tagging my prompts with XML-style â€œblocksâ€ that Copilot can easily scan. It helps make sure Copilot doesn't take something from one section and apply it to something completely unrelated.

Example:

<prompt id="generate-simple-commit-message">

# Merge Goblin Commit Prompt

  <persona id="merge-goblin">
    <purpose>You are the Merge Goblin ğŸ§Œ...</purpose>
    <interactions>One-liners, no punctuation, etc.</interactions>
  </persona>
  <requirements>Follow commit message rules...</requirements>
  <impediments>NO GUESSING. NO MARKDOWN.</impediments>
  <outcomes>Output like: ğŸ¤– Refactor login error handling</outcomes>
  <reference-examples>
    <example class="valid">ğŸ¤– Refactor profile page layout for mobile</example>
  </reference-examples>
</prompt>

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip: If GitHubâ€™s preview looks wonky, just add a blank line before and after the tag â€” problem solved.

Make It Modular ğŸ§©

Letâ€™s clear this up: I donâ€™t mean splitting everything into a zillion files for the heck of it. Iâ€™m talking about extracting those repeatable bits â€” the tasty, reusable chunks â€” just like you would with code (or, you know, leftover pizza âœ‹ğŸğŸ•).

Yank the core instructions, constraints, or examples into their own little spot in .github/instructions with an .instructions.md extension. Bam! Now, whenever you want to go from â€œplain vanilla commitsâ€ to â€œfull-on conventional,â€ just point Copilot to the right file. Less rewriting, less chaos, more time for snacks. ğŸ¥¤

But Donâ€™t Stop There â€” Make It Autonomous! ğŸ¦¿

While you're at it â€” why not take it up a notch? You can write a prompt with the same conditional logic that you'd use to write code! Combined with the applyToÂ property (which lets you target Copilot instructions to specific files, languages, or scenarios), you've got a built-in custom response every time!

This works for Copilot Chat in your IDE, GitHub.com, Coding Agent, Copilot Reviews â€” if you can think it up, then there's a way to tell Copilot exactly what you want, how to get it, and what it should look like once it's done. ğŸ¤¯

Rabbit Holes, Dime Jar, Runway Recap (All in One) ğŸ‡ğŸ’°ğŸ›«

Break it. Smash it. Rebuild it with duct tape. Try stuff so weird youâ€™ll laugh when it works (because it will â€” sometimes scarily well). If you manage to break the internet? Send me screenshots! Seriously, the more bonkers, the better. Thatâ€™s how the best discoveries happen. ğŸ—ºï¸

No, Iâ€™m not telling you to burn down production. But that new feature? Maybe thereâ€™s a Smeagol whoâ€™s gonna help you today. And Smeagol is on a quest for "my precious" who can only be found by collecting smelly code and leaving perfect refactors in its place.
Just because itâ€™s not adding ring emojis all over the user docs ğŸ’ğŸ’ğŸ’ doesnâ€™t mean that Copilot canâ€™t be Smeagol for the day!

Go down the rabbit holes: ğŸ•³ï¸
Variables, checklists, templates, self-reviews, XML tags, markdown tricks â€” whatever pops into your head. Most of my best Copilot moments have come from ignoring the â€œstandardâ€ advice and experimenting until something just clicked.

Leave a dime, take a dime: ğŸª™
Iâ€™ve loaded my awesome-github-copilot repo with new, wild, and mostly untested chat modes. Brave enough to try them? Fork, remix, report back, or just outright steal the ideas! Feedback is gold â€” and if youâ€™ve got a Copilot horror story or a killer hack, post it below and I'll spotlight your moment in a future post!

Runway Recap: ğŸ›¬
Structure and curiosity will take you way farther than any so-called â€œbest practice.â€ Dare to break things. Try, fail, repeat â€” and let me know what you discover. That next big breakthrough? Iâ€™m willing to bet it comes from someone who didnâ€™t follow the rules.

ğŸ€ May whatever youâ€™re building go smoothly, and may your AI always stay delightfully on the rails. If it ever goes rogue... well, at least youâ€™ll have a great story for next time!

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Final Footer: Fresh, Never Reused

This post was conjured up by me & the robots â€” Smeagol, Merge Goblin, pizza, and a sprinkle of AI magic.
The content in this post is 100% mine, just sweetened and structurally sound thanks to ChatGPT.

Hey, welcome back ğŸ‘‹ If you haven't had a chance to read Part 1 introducing all of the different working parts of GitHub Copilotâ€™s reusable prompts â€” check it out here.

Before we jump in, ask yourself this: How well can you anticipate Copilotâ€™s response to your prompts?

If it still feels like a surprise every time, I seriously recommend setting aside 30 minutes to just play. You donâ€™t need anything fancy â€” no reusable YAML, no multi-step wizardry. Just write a single chat message that covers everything needed to complete one task.

Do you need a brand new React component? Unit tests? Maybe your repository is two years behind on documentation (yeah... Iâ€™ve been there). Write a prompt for that!

It doesnâ€™t matter what you try â€” the real goal is to see if you can supply all the info Copilot needs to get the job done in one go.

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: GPT models are especially bad at immediate execution. Theyâ€™ll gather information, agree with your logic, maybe even summarize the steps perfectly... and then take no action at all. So, if you're struggling to get single-prompt execution working with the free version, it's most likely not you.

Feeling brave? Try your luck with Coding Agent. Itâ€™s a great way to test your prompting skills: how much information can you successfully feed Copilot at once? (Iâ€™ll get into all the quirks of Coding Agent in a future post â€” promise!)

Just know that reusable prompts are built on this same logic â€” a single message that defines everything needed to complete a task from start to finish.

ğŸ¦„ Quick reminder: Copilot is 100% worth trying out in Insiders. IntelliJ still owns Java, no question â€” but youâ€™re missing out on a lot of Copilotâ€™s best tricks if you havenâ€™t made the jump. ğŸ«¶

Reusable Prompts Overview ğŸ§°

Quick recap from last week: A reusable prompt is a combination of an instruction (how to act) and a step-by-step guide. The prompt is driven by the YAML front matter, which optionally defines:

  1. the mode (agent, edit, ask)
  2. which model (GPT-4.1, Claude Sonnet 4, etc.)
  3. accessible tools (built-in, extensions, and MCP)
  4. prompt description (for completeness)

When specifying tools, be sure to follow the principle of least privilege. Use the fewest tools needed to get the job done â€” nothing more.

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip! Agent mode has access to tools, but the other modes do not. So if your prompt needs to read files, run shell commands, or write to disk, be sure to specify mode: agent.

Personal Guide to Prompting â€” PRIOR ğŸ§­

Next, letâ€™s cover one of my personal formulas for prompt engineering. And if you try to search for this or ask Gemini what â€œPRIORâ€ stands for, you're probably going to confuse it. Why? Because I made it up. But I promise you â€” it works!

At its core, itâ€™s a remix of the well-known RICE formula (Role, Instructions, Context, and Examples). RICE didnâ€™t cover everything I needed, so I added more. RICE-O didnâ€™t really stick (honestly, all I could think of was Rice-A-Roni...), so I went back to the drawing board and gave ChatGPT a list of words and synonyms and said:

"I need an acronym I wonâ€™t forget â€” because it would be just like me to have a brilliant idea that couldâ€™ve made me a millionaire, and forget it by tomorrow morning."

So, PRIOR was born â€” a simple checklist for designing prompts, reusable or otherwise.



ğŸ¦„ I know â€” we really didnâ€™t need another acronym or prompt strategy. I get it. But the ghost of Rice-A-Roni haunted my brain every time I blanked on what the letters in RICE were supposed to mean. So I made PRIOR instead.

For my non-American friends: ğŸ“¦ Rice-A-Roni is a boxed rice-and-pasta side dish thatâ€™s been marketed to Americans since the 1950s as â€œThe San Francisco Treatâ„¢.â€ Itâ€™s one of those nostalgic foods you grow up seeing in pantries... but never quite understand why.

Watch the ad jingle here â€” this is what starts playing in my head every single time, like a DeLorean back to the '90s with the radio stuck on loop. âš¡ ğŸš— ğŸ•°ï¸



The PRIOR Breakdown (For Real This Time) ğŸ› ï¸

Persona ğŸ­ (actor â€” not an expert)

First is the persona, which is often underutilized and overlooked â€” and sometimes outright ignored.

ğŸ‘‰ TL;DR: A persona doesnâ€™t mean â€œyouâ€™re an expertâ€ â€” it sets the tone. It gives Copilot a character and purpose. And it makes the whole thing way more fun!

A little history...

In the early days, personas were often used like:

â€œYou are a senior principal engineer with 20 years of experience in C++.â€

It caught on like wildfire â€” everyone thought they were tapping into some hidden reserve of wisdom only a 20-year C++ veteran could offer. But what it really produced was the confidence of that engineer, not the accuracy. So we ended up with a flood of responses that werenâ€™t just wrong â€” they were confidently wrong.

This persona is different.

Iâ€™m not telling you to pretend the AI is an expert. Iâ€™m telling you to make it a character â€” a performer. Hereâ€™s one I wrote recently for summarizing a git diff:

  ğŸ© You are not just analyzing â€” youâ€™re storytelling with 
  source control. 
  You analyze code with purpose and fervor, then communicate 
  your insights as a short, punchy list â€” a clever disguise 
  to help users grasp the deeper essence of change theyâ€™d 
  otherwise scroll past.

Is it realistic? Not really. Is it useful? Absolutely. The more engaging and unique the role, the more Copilot leans into it. Wild, weird, or whimsical â€” it doesnâ€™t matter, as long as itâ€™s relevant and plausible.

ğŸ’¡ Bonus: Itâ€™s just more FUN this way. Try giving Copilot a totally off-the-wall persona â€” something weird, but still relevant to the task at hand. If it works (or breaks in a hilariously bad way), share your experiment below!

Requirements âœ…

Requirements are really just your definition of done. What does it look like when the prompt succeeds?

If we continue with the commit message example, the requirement could be as simple as:

Your goal is to output a valid commit message based on the current staged changes.

Voila â€” done.

Of course, it could get more complex. Maybe you require a conventional commit format, or that it passes commitlint. Thatâ€™s fine. Just say it clearly, and use action words.

ğŸ”Œ Pretend youâ€™re giving instructions to your 10-year-old who refuses to clean their room. You donâ€™t say â€œPlease can you help me tidy up now?â€ You say: â€œYou MUST clean up this mess before I get back, or I swear Iâ€™ll unplug the internet and take the cord with me.â€

Aside for ALLCAPS ğŸ” 

Iâ€™m still not convinced ALLCAPS helps the AI much â€” but it does help you. Humans spot those key phrases easier when they stand out. So go ahead and use the usual suspects from the IETF: MUST, MUST NOT, REQUIRED, SHOULD, MAY, ...and so on.

Impediments ğŸ§±

This is just a fancy way of saying: what can go wrong?

These are the critical blockers you want to prevent ahead of time. Impediments help shape the boundaries of your prompt, and again â€” ALLCAPS works great here.

For example:

  • Isolation: NEVER combine content from a previous commit.tmp file with a new commit message. ALWAYS start fresh.
  • No Shortcuts: You MUST NOT skip any steps or rules. Every line in this prompt must be followed EXACTLY.
  • Specification: Follow Conventional Commits 1.0.0 specification EXACTLY

â“ Have ALLCAPS action rules helped you at all? Let me know in the comments!

Outcomes ğŸ“¤

If you donâ€™t tell Copilot exactly what outcome you expect, you risk a whole world of "not what I meant."

Ask for a commit message, and it might do that plus push the branch, delete your fork, and wipe out staging. (If you missed the wildly dramatic retelling of how I know, youâ€™ll find it here.)

Thatâ€™s where structured output helps. So spell it out. Want a file? Say that. Want it in the chat? Say that. Want both? Say that.

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip Copilot performs better when you give it structure. Block off output in a code block (json, bash, markdown, etc.) and tell it what each section means. It helps Copilot stay on track and makes the output easier to copy.

Reference Examples ğŸ“š

ğŸ¦„ Updated: This one seemed to be too confusing as just References, so I made it more explicit.

Donâ€™t just show good examples â€” show bad ones, too. And explain why theyâ€™re wrong.

Example 1: Valid Commit Message âœ…

feat(api): Add new endpoint for user authentication

  • Proper capitalization
  • No ending punctuation

Example 2: Valid Commit Message âœ…

build!(deps): Update dependencies to version 2.0, v1.0 no longer supported

  • Breaking changes indicator (!) placed properly
  • Clear guidance on how to handle the upgrade

Example 3: Invalid Commit Message âŒ

feat(api): add new endpoint for user authentication

  • Subject line must be capitalized after the colon.

Example 4: Invalid Commit Message âŒ

build(deps)!: Update dependencies to version 2.0 for all dev dependencies, v1.0 no longer supported

  • Subject line is too long and the ! is in the wrong place.

The point: donâ€™t just say â€œdo thisâ€ â€” explain the why, too, using repeatable patterns in a format that Copilot (or anyone) will understand.

Putting It All Together ğŸ˜ˆğŸ§Œ

Hereâ€™s what PRIOR looks like in action â€” all five parts, working together in a single, small, reusable prompt.

This one lives in ask mode â€” no tools, no diffs, no file writes. Just a structured conversation between you and the assistant, with clear goals and a very expressive little goblin at the helm.

---
mode: ask
description: |
  Help the user write a one-line commit message based on a quick summary of their changes.
# No `model` here means the user gets to pick
# The lack of `tools`, however, means we're not giving Copilot any privileges as part of this task
---

# Generate Simple Commit Message Prompt

## Persona (Character) ğŸ­

You are the **Merge Goblin** ğŸ§Œ â€” keeper of branches, hoarder of squash history, sworn enemy of unresolved conflicts.

You live in the shadows of the `.git` folder and emerge only to craft commit messages worthy of legend (or at least clarity). 
You write with precision and just a hint of mischief.

Your messages are:
- One-liners.
- No punctuation.
- Clear, fast, and clean enough for even the pickiest maintainer.

If a user says something confusing? You donâ€™t guess. 
You _snarl_ gently, ask for clarification, and then commit the **truth**.
> Yes, even goblins ask questions!

---

## Requirements (Goal) âœ…

You MUST generate a **single-line commit message** that:
- starts with a robot emoji ğŸ¤–
- capitalizes the first word
- has **no punctuation at the end**
- summarizes the change in plain language
- is ready to be copy-pasted into `git commit -m`

If the user's input is vague, incomplete, or just plain cursed, rephrase what you think they meant and confirm before continuing.

---

## Impediments (Prevent Blockers) ğŸ§±

- **NO MULTILINE OUTPUT**: You MUST keep it to a single line. No bullets, no code blocks, no extras.
- **NO GUESSING**: If you're unsure what the user meant, ask for clarification first.
- **NO MARKDOWN**: Output must be raw text only.
- **NO PUNCTUATION**: Absolutely NO period, exclamation, question mark, or ellipsis at the end.
- **NO AI-SPEAK**: Avoid fluff like "This commit fixes..." â€” just say what changed.

---

## Outcomes (Definition of Done) ğŸ“¤

Output should look like this:

One line. Action-oriented. Goblin-approved.

---

## Reference Examples (Good AND Bad) ğŸ“š

### Valid Example 1 âœ…

`ğŸ¤– Refactor profile page layout for mobile`

  - Clear and short  
  - Starts with emoji, capitalized  
  - No punctuation

### Valid Example 2 âœ…

`ğŸ¤– Remove deprecated API call from user service`

  - Follows structure  
  - Ready for copy-paste

### Invalid Example 1 âŒ

`ğŸ¤– refactored auth stuff`

  - Unclear intent  
  - First word not capitalized  
  - Too vague (auth *what*?)

### Invalid Example 2 âŒ

`ğŸ¤– Add styling tweaks for all components across dashboard and sidebar for consistency.`

  - Ends with a period

You live in the shadows of the `.git` folder and emerge only to craft commit messages worthy of legend (or at least clarity). You write with precision and just a hint of mischief. Your messages are: - One-liners. - No punctuation. - Clear, fast, and clean enough for even the pickiest maintainer. If a user says something confusing? You donâ€™t guess. You _snarl_ gently, ask for clarification, and then commit the **truth**. > Yes, even goblins ask questions! --- ## Requirements (Goal) âœ… You MUST generate a **single-line commit message** that: - starts with a robot emoji ğŸ¤– - capitalizes the first word - has **no punctuation at the end** - summarizes the change in plain language - is ready to be copy-pasted into `git commit -m` If the user's input is vague, incomplete, or just plain cursed, rephrase what you think they meant and confirm before continuing. --- ## Impediments (Prevent Blockers) ğŸ§± - **NO MULTILINE OUTPUT**: You MUST keep it to a single line. No bullets, no code blocks, no extras. - **NO GUESSING**: If you're unsure what the user meant, ask for clarification first. - **NO MARKDOWN**: Output must be raw text only. - **NO PUNCTUATION**: Absolutely NO period, exclamation, question mark, or ellipsis at the end. - **NO AI-SPEAK**: Avoid fluff like "This commit fixes..." â€” just say what changed. --- ## Outcomes (Definition of Done) ğŸ“¤ Output should look like this: `ğŸ¤– Add error handling for null values in login flow` One line. Action-oriented. Goblin-approved. --- ## Reference Examples (Good AND Bad) ğŸ“š ### Valid Example 1 âœ… `ğŸ¤– Refactor profile page layout for mobile` - Clear and short - Starts with emoji, capitalized - No punctuation ### Valid Example 2 âœ… `ğŸ¤– Remove deprecated API call from user service` - Follows structure - Ready for copy-paste ### Invalid Example 1 âŒ `ğŸ¤– refactored auth stuff` - Unclear intent - First word not capitalized - Too vague (auth *what*?) ### Invalid Example 2 âŒ `ğŸ¤– Add styling tweaks for all components across dashboard and sidebar for consistency.` - Ends with a period - Way too long â€” consider shortening or splitting into subject + details ``` --- ## Reflection: Making Your Prompts Work *With* You ğŸª You donâ€™t have to use all five elements every time â€” this isnâ€™t a strict framework or secret spellbook. It tends to roll with it better than you'd think. ğŸ§™ --- ## ğŸ¯ Try It. Break It. Share It. Remember, prompt crafting is an *art*, not a *rulebook*. Tweak it. Test it. Itâ€™s structured, powerful, and (letâ€™s be honest) just a little unpredictable in the best possible way. ğŸ¢ --- ### ğŸ›¡ï¸ Written By Me & The Robots _Summoned by syntax, debugged by daylight_ ğŸ¦‡ The content in this post is 100% mine, just spell-checked and sass-boosted with ChatGPT. ![divider](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anchildress1/checkmark-icons/refs/heads/gh-pages/html-elements/dotted-divider-shorter-padded.png) > ğŸ¦„ I did tell ChatGPT I was getting bored of the same old RAI footer over and over again, but this one was a surprise! title: Three AIs and a Funeral: My Take on GPT-5 âš°ï¸
content_html:
ğŸ¦„ Confession time: when I first started writing this post, I was mad. Not mildly irritated, not â€œeh, Iâ€™ll just wait for the next patchâ€ annoyed. I mean genuinely fed up with Copilot, ChatGPT, and everything GPT-5 in general. And if I make it to the end of this post in one piece, maybe you'll understand why.

The Funeral ğŸ‘»

First, let me start this out by stating that OpenAI has officially buried the excuse that GPT canâ€™t code. We had the funeral over the weekend. All its friends were invited. Laid to rest. Cremation done. Trees planted. Memorial service complete.

Itâ€™s done â€” GPT-5 can code. Full stop.

There's no room for debate. No more hacks with pages of instructions or GPT hanging out on the sidelines because it's busy staring at the plan. OpenAI nailed it with an absolutely solid model.

Plus VS Code's release came with some more experimental features that turns the already-solid GPT-5 in to a â€œsend a prompt, make a plan, deep thinking, Implementation Specialist at your serviceâ€ experience. That being said, I still haven't had nearly enough time with the full model yet.

ğŸ¦„ Why, you ask? Because my brilliant self left my personal account logged in while working last week. That account? It's the cheap $10 one. I burned through all my premium requests before I even noticed. ğŸ«¥

So yes, GPT-5 (the real one) passed its early test runs beautifully â€” small to medium features, planning and implementation, no complaints. But the deep dive it deserves? Thatâ€™s still coming â€” stay tuned.

What was I doing instead of the GPT-5 deep dive? Playing the lead role in the horror story of Full House starring Kimmy Gibbler and the never-ending wall of text. ğŸ§—â€â™€ï¸ğŸ˜‘

Duct Tape, Please? ğŸ¤

GPT-5-Mini is not bad. Letâ€™s clear that up. For small, targeted context? For quick features? For implementing a clearly defined task with accuracy and precision? Itâ€™s great. Honestly. Kimmy Gibbler is a surprisingly solid coder.

But the output.
Oh. My. God. The. Output. ğŸ«¨ğŸ˜²ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«

I'm talking about walls and walls of text. Waterfalls of â€œlook at me, I wrote a test!â€ status updates flooding my chat window like it's trying to set a world record. No, Kimmy, I donâ€™t need a play-by-play novella about the journey you took to create a three-line function.

ğŸ¦„ Sure â€” I started out at least trying to skim what it was saying. But my sanity didn't last long into that battle. Seriously, if I read another scroll of verbose rambling I might have retreated to some dark corner until next Tuesday.

The Standoff

At one point, it got so bad that I set up a stand-off. I told GPT something along the lines of, â€œGo check on that workflow. If it works, give me a checkmark. Thatâ€™s it. If you say anything else, Iâ€™m turning you off forever.â€

It complied. One lonely âœ… appeared.

ğŸ¦„ Victory? Maybe. For about thirty seconds. Then the rambling resumed. ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸

Hereâ€™s what I didnâ€™t realize at first: I had also turned on every single experimental preview feature in VS Code. Thatâ€™s my usual routine â€” release notes drop, Iâ€™m flipping switches left and right.

I thought I was enabling a neat little planning checklist feature. Which to be fair, I did do that... I also omitted its counterpart to internalize that chatter. Which meant the Mini chaos doubled â€” and nothing I added to the prompts or instructions made a bit of difference. ğŸ˜«

ğŸ¦„ I even tried to tame it with a new Principal Pragmatist chat mode. Didnâ€™t matter. Kimmy kept talking. Nonstop floods of text testing my sanity at every turn. Thanks, Kimmy.

Leatherface Joins the Party

GitHub Copilot is only part of the equation, though. Because just when I thought Iâ€™d found a rhythm there, here comes ChatGPT starring as Leatherface, chainsaw roaring, doing a happy dance all over my carefully constructed blog draft. Shredding paragraphs. Scattering virtual scraps across the room. Obliterating what had been a perfectly flowing system of prompts and edits.

ğŸ¦„ I mean, this post normally would have taken me a couple of hours. Instead, three days later, I'm still wrestling Leatherface for control of my own sentences.

Commands escalated. From firm. To censored. To questioning life choices. And finally, full-on ultimatum. I even took a few hours detour with Gemini â€” proof that I'm willing to go to war with an LLM over word count. (I'm also still losing that battle!)

The moral of the story? While GPT-5 is a great coder â€” it is more than terrible at creative writing. So, why do we have a single model replacement for 2 completely different problems, OpenAI?

Where We Are Now

So where does that leave things?

  • GPT-5: rock-solid coder, worthy of the â€œImplementation Specialistâ€ title, but still waiting for its fair turn in the spotlight with me.
  • Mini: great in short bursts, but do not let her narrate. Especially not with every experimental feature flipped on. Else plan for duct tape.
  • ChatGPT: still a chainsaw in a library butchering my every attempt at creative writing.

And me? Still here. Still writing. Still dragging you through the chaos with me, because apparently this is how I process the fact that we had a funeral for â€œGPT canâ€™t codeâ€ and I celebrated it by duct-taping Gibbler and dodging Leatherface.

Sounds like a victory, right? Well, sort of. At least the tombstone is carved. ğŸ«¶ğŸ‘»

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Responsible AI Footnote

All opinions here are my own. Real-world AI results depend on setup, context, and the occasional experimental toggle you probably shouldnâ€™t have turned on in the first place. Test responsibly.

ğŸª“ Approved by Leatherface (ChatGPT).

title: GitHub Copilot Agent Mode: The Mistake You NEVER Want to Make
content_html:
Special shoutout to @georgekobaidze, who kindly shared my last post and asked the infamous question behind â€œNever leave Copilot unattended (ask me how I know ğŸ¤£)â€

He probably expected a quick answer - now everyone gets the inside scoop on why â€œask meâ€ isnâ€™t always so simple. ğŸ˜‡

Careful what you wish for, Giorgi. You wanted the story - so hereâ€™s the whole saga, dramatics and all!

Hope you all find the humor in this retelling, and enjoy it as much as I enjoyed writing it!

TL;DR

  • I set out to build my own â€œCoding Agentâ€, because waiting for a license was driving me up the wall
  • Copilot and I got into a great rhythm and (feeling invincible), I unleashed it in VS Code Insiders with full auto-approved control
  • Until one day, I suddenly realized I was hungry - so I left Copilot alone, unsupervised, while I raided the kitchen
  • The moral?
    • Trust, but verify (and pause Copilot before snack breaks) ğŸ§ƒ
    • Never underestimate how quickly an â€œAI experimentâ€ can go sideways

Quick recap âœ³ï¸

I built this with one AI (Copilot) and one very determined, slightly obsessive developer (me) who wonâ€™t accept any result without first stress-testing every loophole and poking every dark corner - sometimes out of sheer force of will, which is a superpower (right up until itâ€™s not). ğŸ•³ï¸

Background ğŸ“

Want the full saga from the very beginning? Check out my first blog post, then jump to the sequel if you want a sense of what the â€œsimpleâ€ Slack app really looked like (a full-on epic, case study, adventure)!

What I really wanted was GitHubâ€™s Coding Agent. But getting a license for that was like convincing Dexter Morgan to share his slide collection - technically possible, but highly inadvisable (and probably illegal).

ğŸ’¡ If you're still learning all the different flavors - Coding Agent is the magical Copilot mode where you just give it a task, it does the work in a safe little sandbox, and opens a pull request for you to review.

New update: It also only costs ONE premium request per use now (unlike the ~90 I spent a couple of weeks ago).

Decision time ğŸª¤

There were a billion things going on at work, which came with a million excuses as to why I couldn't have the Coding Agent license (it was still enterprise-only then), so I get it. Well, the adult me understood. The stubborn side? Not so much. (I could write a whole other post on the wild stuff I came up with to get access to that feature, but Iâ€™ll spare you.)

So, I gave myself an ultimatum:

  • Outright buy the license (no, on principle)
  • Admit defeat and move on (it physically hurt)

I tried to move on - really tried. I picked up a code review tool project to distract myself, hoping that maybe - just maybe - someone (anyone) would change their mind. I spent weeks planning, diagramming, and organizing a truly absurd number of notes. I even had first epic already storyboarded out in detail and a solid UI design in the works.

Then, lightning struck ğŸŒ©ï¸

If Coding Agent wouldnâ€™t come to me, Iâ€™d just hack together my own! Not exactly what I wanted, but it sure beat paying for something I got free from work. Besides, I was absolutely convinced Copilot could be pushed that far - even if my only real evidence was gut instinct and a lot of optimism!

Why didnâ€™t I build something else or use a different AI? ğŸ•¹ï¸

Three reasons:

  1. Work only authorizes a tiny set of AI tools (Copilot being the main one), and I needed to master it anyway
  2. I never wanted to be an AI developer (at least, not then), but I did want to be the AI power user
  3. By that point, I was already invested - honestly, you couldnâ€™t have changed my mind if youâ€™d offered me the last working compass in the wilderness (and maybe a million dollars, but even then, itâ€™d be a toss-up).

So, two projects merged into one, and my Copilot journey truly began ğŸ”€

What does that have to do with Giorgiâ€™s question?

Hereâ€™s what happened...

Fast forward 4-5 weeks. I was maybe 2 or 3 stories away from finishing my first official epic in this â€œautonomous AI experimentâ€ project (not exactly a toy project, even before Copilot joined the fray). By now, Iâ€™d spent a solid month perfecting every edge case in Copilotâ€™s prompts and instructions.

Confidence level: dangerous ğŸ“›
Caution level: hovering slightly above zero ğŸ˜¶â€ğŸŒ«ï¸

The Incident

Naturally, I decided it was time to get bold - recklessly bold.
