content_html:
Surviving Premium Limits & Leveling Up with Custom Instructions

If youâ€™re the kind of dev who treats Copilotâ€™s agent mode like your own private coding butler (and not just a fancier autocomplete), youâ€™ve probably bumped into some premium request limits. I sure didâ€”hard enough to get shut down after just four days of bouncing between 4â€“5 active projects with Claude models. Whoops.

But instead of a doom spiral, I figured: letâ€™s share whatâ€™s actually working, and help someone else avoid my mistakes (and my, uh, "Baby Billy on water skis" level of desperation to get back to coding ğŸ¦†â›·ï¸).

TL;DR I'm at a full stop for the moment thanks to this giant red 0 on the page, so I decided to take some time to put together some of the things that's really worked well for me when using Copilot. Here's hoping someone else can avoid some of the mistakes I made early on.

ğŸ› ï¸ My Real-World Copilot Agent Workflow

1. Repository-Specific Instructions ğŸ“’

The real MVP for me? The .github/copilot-instructions.md file.

  • Copilot automatically reads this if it exists in your repo.
  • Whatever you put here is context for every chat interaction in that repo - it travels across users and IDEs.
  • Start small! Define the basics and add specific instructions only as Copilot demonstrates where it gets confused or off track.
  • Example: Tell Copilot to summarize its goal & action plan every so often, or ask it to verify a step before continuing. 
## Purpose
- Summarize your current goal before making changes. 
- For every code edit, output a short plan first.

## Persona
- Assume the user is new to the codebase.

## Technologies
- This repo was recently upgraded to Java 21 from version 17.
- ALWAYS write new code using the latest standards and best practices

ğŸ”— Learn more about repo-specific Copilot instructions here

2. Keep Chats Contained ğŸ—‚ï¸

Donâ€™t just let a chat run forever. The context window is limitedâ€”so start a new Copilot Agent chat for each new topic, user story, or bug.

  • Pro tip: Close all unrelated files in VS Code to reduce distractions for Copilot. ğŸ§¹
  • History button (the little clock ğŸ•°ï¸) can help you pick up a previous session if needed.
  • Watch your limits Premium requests pile up quickly, so encourage Copilot to prompt the user before ending the request prematurely.

3. Limit the Blast Radius ğŸ’¥

Try not to tackle everything at once.

  • Use Ask Mode (the GPT models ğŸ§ ) to brainstorm ideas, flesh out requirements, and get Copilotâ€™s suggestions.
  • For each implementation, switch to Agent mode and work one story at a time.
  • Encourage Copilot to implement incrementallyâ€”have it plan, then check, then execute. ğŸ¦¾ 
# Story: Add User Login

**Goal:** Implement secure user authentication.
**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Login with email & password
- JWT token issued on success
- Error shown on failure

4. Iterative Prompt Engineering ğŸ§¬

Change instructions slowly and only when youâ€™re sure you understand how Copilot is misbehaving.

  • I canâ€™t count the number of times I thought I had a clever instruction, only to watch Copilot go rogue and turn my codebase into spaghetti ğŸ¤–ğŸ.
  • Want ideas? Search GitHub for copilot-instructions.md and see what others are doing.

5. Encourage Copilot to Self-Check ğŸ¦‰

If Copilot starts acting weird (editing the wrong files, doing something unexpected), hit pause â¸ï¸ and ask it to explain its plan.

  • If the answer makes sense, tell it to continue â–¶ï¸.
  • If not, youâ€™ve given it a chance to self-correct before things go totally off the rails ğŸš‚.

6. Let Copilot Write Its Own Instructions âœï¸ğŸ¤–

Yes, really! Start an Ask chat, put your repo in context, and prompt Copilot:

â€œWrite your own repo-specific instructions based on the structure and common pitfalls you see.â€

ğŸ“ Bonus: What to Put In Your Instructions

title: GitHub Copilot: Everything You Wanted to Know About Reusable (and Experimental) Prompts - Part 1
content_html:
ğŸ˜‡ Confession: I started planning this post over a month ago, got sidetracked this weekend (at least four times), half-wrote a completely different post, and only finished this one at the last minute after I started writing from the end. Thatâ€™s just how it goes in my head - always at full throttle, but rarely in a straight line. ğŸŒªï¸

So grab your favorite over-caffeinated iced drink (mine: grande, iced midnight, extra espresso, real vanilla cream - liquid chaos in a cup â˜•ï¸â£ï¸) and settle in. Hereâ€™s everything I know about Copilotâ€™s reusable prompts - Part 1.

Why This Isnâ€™t Another Wall of Copilot Prompts ğŸ§±

Have you ever searched for best practices when it comes to Copilot? You usually end up with either a block that can't even be considered a whole sentence on it's own OR the wall is so gigantic you don't even know where to start reading?

You're really curious though - so you dive in at the first place you see, and then last about 30 seconds... About the time all those AI lines start to blur together you think, â€œThereâ€™s no way anyone actually does all this in real life?â€

Honestly, Iâ€™m probably that person who wrote half the wall (or more) to begin with! Good news for you though, is that:

  1. I'm not going to do that do you now, and
  2. I do a great job of finding out all the things that absolutely will not work no matter what you try (so you don't have to!) â˜ºï¸

Here's my "boiled-down-to basics" version of GitHub Copilot's Reusable (and still experimental) Prompts.

âœ¨ğŸ“ Copilotâ€™s File Types, Explained

Ever wonder how Copilot instructions and prompts show up in real life? Hereâ€™s what it actually looks like in a real project:

â–º .github/copilot-instructions.md â€” This is your repoâ€™s â€œhow to actâ€ guide for Copilot and is always in context. It sets the baseline behavior for your project and tells Copilot what to expect from your workflow and contributors.

Using what you know about our current release system, write a git command to view the total number of commits pushed to main since the last tagged version.

â–º .github/instructions/secure-coding-principles.instruction.md â€” Think of this as a reusable, specialized playbook. Use these for rules or guidelines you want Copilot to follow everywhere, or for specific situations - like always doing a security review, or making sure React code has matching tests.

With rules defined in #secure-coding-principles.instruction.md, perform a thorough code review of all staged changes. When you are finished, post a new pull request review with all your comments or suggestions for changes to meet minimum guidelines defined by this repo.
---
With everything you know from the #rules-for-react.instruction.md, build a new component for the frontend along with unit and integration tests.

â–º .github/prompts/something-for-copilot-to-do-regularly.prompt.md â€” This is where you automate repeatable workflows. Itâ€™s a set of step-by-step instructions Copilot can follow whenever you trigger it with a slash command in chat.

/generate-conventional-commit using only staged changes for JIRA-1234.

ğŸ‰ Who needs to memorize Vim macros or survive Emacs keybindings when you can just hit â€œ/â€ in the chat and watch Copilot handle the rest?

Quick Review ğŸ“•

ğŸ’¡ Not on VS Code (or Insiders) yet? Nowâ€™s your chance to give it a real shot - features like this hit VS Code Insiders months before anywhere else. For now, itâ€™s the best way to test reusable prompts hands-on, so go ahead and grab it if you havenâ€™t already.

I know Iâ€™ve written a lot about models - like in AI Coding with GitHub Copilot and Troubleshooting Production with GitHub Copilot - but I havenâ€™t spent much time on chat modes.

ğŸ’ And no, not the same as "Custom Chat Modes" (which is also super cool - I promise Iâ€™ll cover those soon!).

Before we jump in, letâ€™s hit pause and rewind. Itâ€™s time for a quick, back-to-basics look at what actually matters when deciding what work you want Copilot to do - and how much control you want over how it gets done.

Chat Modes at a Glance ğŸ›ï¸

Hereâ€™s where things get interesting: Copilot doesnâ€™t just work in one â€œmodeâ€ - itâ€™s got a whole range, from chill Q&A to full-on automation beast. Pick your mode wisely!

Mode What It Does When To Use Power Level
Ask Answers questions, suggests ideas - your personal Stack Overflow, minus the snark. Research, quick advice, copy snippets ğŸŸ¢ Low
Edit Changes code in-place, optimized for speedâ€”think â€œfind and replace,â€ but actually smart. Step-by-step or explicit code changes ğŸŸ¡ Medium
Agent Multi-step, can use tools, context, and reasoning. Give it instructions and let it run wild (within reason). Automation, complex flows, integrations ğŸ”´ High
Custom Depends on it's goal from the user... so many choices! Automation, complex flows, integrations, team magic ğŸ’œ Extreme

ğŸ¦„ Let me know how curious you are about these custom chat modes - I'm still experimenting and figuring out what they can (and can't) do. If youâ€™ve got questions, wild theories, or even better, your own examples... drop them in the comments! ğŸš¦ğŸ’¬

The Gist of Models ğŸ¦¾

âœ¨ I know, I reuse this table a lot - but hey, good models deserve a callback.

Model Best For Notes & Quirks
GPT-4.1, GPT-4o Creative debugging, â€œWhere do I start?â€ Needs hand-holding on long tasks. Free for most users.
o3/4-mini, Gemini Pattern-matching, log sleuthing Great for â€œexplain these logs,â€ not for wild creative leaps.
Gemini 2.5 Tedious but simple, long-form tasks Decent at bulk work, rarely surprises (good or bad).
Claude Sonnet 3.5â€“4 Root cause, deep logic, â€œwhy did this happen?â€ Loves complex analysis but rarely offers alternate approaches unless you nudge.

Tools for your AI ğŸª›

VS Code comes with several tools for GitHub Copilot already built in, but you can always add more via extensions or MCP servers. There's not much to cover here after you know they exist and where to find them. Unless you're making friends with every MCP server and already met your "128 selected tool" limit, there's not much reason to mess with them much. Just make sure they're all selected and available for Copilot to execute when prompted and you're set.Â 

Here's my personal top-5 built-in tools, that somehow alwaysÂ manage to sneak into any reusable prompt I write:

  • #changesÂ gives Copilot the ability to see a git diffÂ for your workspace
  • #codebaseÂ all-season access to your repo (and sometimes should be more targeted, but when in doubt this is a good start!)
  • #runTestsÂ is just what it sounds like and let's Copilot execute any part or all of your test suite
  • #runInTerminalÂ is the basic run-of-the-mill access to Copilot's very own integrated terminal (separate from yours!)
  • #editFilesÂ is the tool Copilot needs to make any changes within your repo. If you're expecting Agent Mode to start implementing features, you're going to need this!

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: In Agent mode, click the wrench (Configure Tools) at the bottom of Copilot Chat to pick exactly which tools Copilot can use. If you share prompts, call out any non-default tools - just like listing dependencies.

Bonus Tools â€” More Power, More Fun ğŸ› ï¸âœ¨ğŸ‰

Some of my favorite extras come from the Atlassian MCP-Remote server, but if you have the ability to install GitHub Apps then check out Rovo, too:

  • #getJiraIssue lets Copilot pull all the details for a story.
  • #addCommentToJiraIssue posts your summary as you (so add your RAI disclaimer!).
  • #createConfluencePage & #updateConfluencePage â€” still figuring out the best way to teach Copilot â€œAtlassian styleâ€ .confluence syntax (itâ€™s a work in progress ğŸ« ).
  • #mermaid-diagram-validator checks your diagrams with the official Mermaid extension.
  • #copilotCodingAgent â€” brand new, and I canâ€™t wait to see what it can do! Assign it a task and let it work while you keep pairing in Copilot Chat.

ğŸ’ Coding Agent has serious limitations, so check the docs before letting it run wild!

ğŸ“¨ Commit Message Magic: One Slash to Rule Them All

Here's an example of a basic, yet realistic prompt that generates a commit message. No Jira, no testing, no terminal magic - just one clear task. This is a great way to test prompt building before layering on more steps or complicated conditional logic.Â 

In VS Code, paste this directly into the promptsÂ folder shown or open the command palette and search for Chat: New Prompt File...Â and then choose whether to store the prompt at the repo-level in .github/promptsÂ or globally for use across all of your workspaces.Â 

Prompt: .github/prompts/generate-commit-message.prompt.md

---
mode: ask
description: |
    This prompt is used to generate a commit message based on changes staged in a Git repository.
tools:
- changes
---

# Generate Commit Changes Prompt

Review all code currently staged and use your chat history, if available, to populate details about the changes. Use the information to generate a concise and informative commit message. It should follow conventional commit standards with a clear type, subject, and bullet points for details.

âš ï¸ UPDATE: The syntax posted above is actually the second version available in VS Code and last night's update seems to have switched it back to the original. So, if you try to load this and see syntax errors try this instead:

  1. description: 'Enter the description in single quotes on the same line and without the |'
  2. tools: ['changes'] <!-- Define in an array instead of a list, with each tool name as a string -->

Executing Reusable Prompts

Once you have this (or any other) reusable prompt stored in VS Code, use a slash command to invoke it in the chat interface. Given the above example, you'd prompt Copilot in the chat with something like

/generate-commit-message consider only staged files and generate a new commit that starts with a unique emoji

Considering all the rules I have set up elsewhere outside of that reusable prompt, I still ended up with a nice clean conventional commit (for the most part).

ğŸ¦„ chore: update commit message generation prompt for clarity

â€¢ Instructs to review all staged code and use chat history for context

title: Guess what?! I passed the Pearson VUE GitHub Copilot Certification Exam ğŸ†âœ¨
content_html:
Okay, technically, Iâ€™ve known this was coming for a while, and honestly, Iâ€™ve felt ready even longer than that. Yes, I celebrated with a gift Leonardo subscription to myself. (Iâ€™ll be way more excited about it once those 429 errors slow down enough for me to actually play with it again.)

Seriously â€” if youâ€™re even considering Leonardo: itâ€™s exploding right now, but if youâ€™re like me (dev brain: â€˜ooh, code banners!â€™), know that Leonardo is pure artist. Artists and devs? Different planets, sometimes.

ğŸ¨ The first time I tossed it a dev prompt: â€œI need a banner image representing a group of diverse engineers upgrading Java with Copilot.â€ I expected... I dunno, coffee? Maybe a way-too-big wrench? Instead: FOUR wildly different, amazing steampunk apocalypse scenes with a diverse squad running away from a tank the size of a data center. ğŸ¤£

Yes, Leonardo â€” sometimes I do feel like that with Java, but it wasnâ€™t exactly what I had in mind! Still, totally worth it just to immortalize Java as the official steampunk language. ğŸš‚âš™ï¸

But letâ€™s set art aside, because:

I did it! I am now officially GitHub Copilot certified! ğŸ«¶

This oneâ€™s been on my list forever, but once Microsoft announced their plan to switch everything to Pearson VUE, I gave it a month before risking the â€œplease excuse our growing painsâ€ phase. So, here we are!

Spoiler: Theyâ€™re still ironing out the kinks. The test itself? Needs work, but passable. The VUE app? Good, even though they made me download it twice, because why not. ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

TL;DR

  • Pearson Vue online process: Better than expected! (Not 100% bug-free, but not a disaster.) ğŸ‘
  • Oâ€™Reilly Copilot prep course: Absolutely worth it (and also pointed out all the places I thought I knew but really needed to revisit) ğŸ“š
  • Giving them a month to get their act together? LOL. Nope. Not nearly enough to fix all the quirks between the doc and real life. â³
  • Iâ€™ll follow up soon with an actual step-by-step for anyone prepping for the GitHub Copilot Certification exam (spoiler: bring snacks â€” youâ€™ll be reading a lot of documentation!) ğŸ¿ğŸ“

Testing Signup & Study Materials ğŸ–¥ï¸ğŸ“„

I signed up via Microsoft Learn (work perk!). The sign-up process was so simple I forgot it even happened. Then I intentionally ignored the looming test until the last second â€” do not recommend, unless youâ€™re also a chronic Copilot abuser (also not recommended!)

Microsoft will port you to Pearson VUE for the real process. Pro tip: for THIS step, do whatever Microsoft tells you. (Only this step. Later? All bets are off.)

Super important: If you use a work/corporate Microsoft account, also link your personal one! Youâ€™ll still get work discounts, but your certification stays with you â€” not the company. Seriously, you do NOT want to have to re-earn this badge if you switch jobs.

If youâ€™re testing online: Read Pearsonâ€™s test space policy. You need an enclosed room, one monitor/laptop, and 3 hours of zero interruptions. Those â€œbathroom testâ€ legends? No longer allowed. No refunds either if you try it and get booted.

Do the Certification Prep + Study! ğŸ“šğŸ’¡

First thing â€” take a prep course! I went with Tim Warnerâ€™s at Oâ€™Reilly (another work perk!)

I expected it to be a snoozefest but nope, itâ€™s actually engaging, and the group vibe is fun. Their class dashboard is super flexible, so get comfy for 4+ hours.

âš ï¸ Warning: the recordings can take up to 2 days after the class, so if you miss part of it, you canâ€™t just catch up right away.

Bonus drama ğŸ§ 

This is also where I learned about â€œbrain dumpâ€ practice tests. Some (like a few on Udemy) get flagged for stolen content, and if you use those, Microsoft can yank your cert for life. Not my rabbit hole, but if anyone has the actual â€œoffendersâ€ list, drop a link in the comments!

Day Before the Test ğŸ•°ï¸ğŸ› ï¸

Picture this: 10pm, my calendar looks more like a merge conflict than any form of organization, and Iâ€™ve just spent a half-day in a prep class (which was great, but just pointed out all the things I thought I knew and needed to go double-check).

Then there's my test space setup: Iâ€™m crammed into the tiniest corner of my house â€” the only space far enough from everyone else, where I can shut the door and (hopefully) not be interrupted. My not-quite-center desk barely fits, squeezed between the footboard and the wall, and thereâ€™s just enough room for me, my laptop, and a single can of Coke.

Not that it was uncomfortable once I got myself situated, but any form of movement meant I was hitting something (mainly myself) on the desk or bed ğŸ›ï¸ğŸ’»ğŸª‘

You won't want to wait until the last minute like I did, but also, thereâ€™s no need to set up a week early. The actual system test:

  1. Download zip > Unzip > Open > Start.
  2. Wait... spinner... okay, done.
  3. Mic, sound, webcam. Check.
  4. Internet + background system. Check.

Donâ€™t use your work computer unless youâ€™re a full admin, with VPN OFF, and you can give full system control to the test app. Restart for a clean slate, and skip the â€œreopen windowsâ€ part. Paperwork? Nada. Until you actually check in. ğŸ—‚ï¸

The truth? My work laptop was more than fine. They stressed the point until I began to worry, but 0 issues. However, I get pretty much free reign with it. If your's is locked up tighter than admin? You could have issues!

Test Day ğŸ¬ğŸ˜

When you register, it defaults to an ungodly early time slot â€” but you can change it to what works for you. (Unless you are that weird morning person who's usually awake with the sun â€” you know who you are â€” just a friendly callout payback ğŸ˜‡).

Sign-In ğŸ›ï¸ğŸ”‘

You can sign in up to 30 minutes early. But the second you open that VUE test app, youâ€™re stuck: no phone, no other apps, no moving. Meaning early birds get to wait longer; last-minute folks like me rush in, power nap, and join the waiting line just in time.

After everyoneâ€™s in the system:

  1. Download app (fresh), system test (again), green light.
  2. Scan your test space
  3. Begin exam

The Picture Game: My Desk, My Rules ğŸ–¼ï¸ğŸ¥¤

Pearson wants 7 pictures, all from your phone:

  • You, against a solid background. Easy.
  • ID, front and back, on a dark surface. Done.
  • Workspace: front, back, left, right...

Insert where I made my first mistake â€” the Pearson Vue phone app lists strict instructions for how they want these pictures. They give you a little diagram to tell you exactly where they want you in relationship to the space when you snap the picture. I'm looking at it and studying... knowing good and well this is not going to work for what they want, but the rules said stand on X so I get as close to X as I can without acrobatics and snap the picture.

Next the "greeter" came online (these are the people responsible for making sure your test area meets all criteria for taking the online exam) and of course the pictures aren't clear enough. So we go through the whole â€œspin aroundâ€ and show the whole room.

Honestly, itâ€™s a live-action improv skit: me, my laptop, and the worldâ€™s smallest mouse trap of a space. Yes, Pearson, it's just a Coke. No, thereâ€™s nothing else hiding in here unless you count my dignity â€” which definitely disappeared between picture three and four. ğŸ™ˆğŸ« 

Exam Begins: More Dramatics Ensue ğŸ«£ğŸ­

Now that's out of the way, we can get down to business. Ready, set, go! Instructions pop up first (read them again). Timer (hide it if you want to stay sane). And Begin. â±ï¸

Iâ€™m focused, in the zone â€” then, out of nowhere: Click. â€œIs there someone in the room with you?â€ Me, blinking at the screen: â€œNo... Oh, wait, I was just talking to myself! I swear I never read a question ouâ€“" Click. Chat window: â€œContinue the exam.â€ ğŸ˜…

Well.. alright then. I guess we're good. Five minutes later â€” interrupted again: â€œIf you donâ€™t stop talking, Iâ€™ll cancel your exam.â€ WHAT?! â€œOkay! Not a problem â€” I'll stop." ğŸ¤

Now I really could have used a break. Microsoft policy explicitly allows unscheduled breaks (timer keeps running, canâ€™t revisit earlier questions). But... I needed to review everything before submitting, so I just clammed up and finished. It was painful!

By the time the exam was over I'm super antsy â€” energy is boiling over from the long stretch of silence â€” but the only thing left is exactly 7 questions I've flagged for feedback to Microsoft (this is the only way you're allowed to mention anything about specific questions after the test is finished). Checked the timer â€” 20 minutes left â€” perfect! ğŸ¤—

I told the proctor, â€œIâ€™m taking a quick break, answers are all submitted.â€ Stepped five feet away, and suddenly, a new proctor:
â€œHello? Are you there? You need to be in front of the camera!â€ Door open, I explained, â€œJust the restroom, all submitted!â€ â€œYou canâ€™t leave the view of the camera.â€ Well, I know they didn't want me to take the computer with me â€” so honestly, what did they want me to do? ğŸ˜²

Confession: I was so done with being polite at that point. I'm already jumping out of my skin from the roaring silence for more than an hour. Now even though Microsoftâ€™s policy says unscheduled breaks are allowed at any point, I'm getting threatened for no reason I can discern.

After three rounds of â€œYou canâ€™t leave!â€ with "But I'm already finished. It's just the feedback." I gave up. â€œAlright â€“ fine! No feedback, then.â€ Click. Click. Done. ...Crickets. ğŸ¦—

I sat there, stunned. Camera turned off, grade popped up â€” yes, I passed, but seriously, what just happened?

Later, I went digging and found a Microsoft blog post from 2022 that clearly shows: <button>â¸ï¸ Take a Break</button>
Did my exam have a break button? NOPE. Well then, THAT explains it. ğŸ˜‘ğŸ™ƒ

Moral of the Story ğŸ’¬

I left a very thorough explanation in Pearson VUEâ€™s feedback form. Yes, I was frustrated, but this isnâ€™t about the proctors or the greeters â€” they were never rude. Itâ€™s either training, documentation, or both!

I wish my voice would have made it to Microsoft, because I had plenty to say about their process and I had spent precious time preparing to do so! Now I just hope the next person either gets that missing break button â€” or at least they update the docs!

Would I do it again? Absolutely! Things happen. This is my dramatic version of events so you donâ€™t have to repeat my mistakes (and hopefully had a little fun along the way). Besides â€” ultimately, I got exactly what I wanted when I started! ğŸ’âœ¨

Nightmare Testing? ğŸ¤ª

If you (or someone you know) have an â€œunexpected twistâ€ or â€œoddly sidewaysâ€ certification or exam story â€” please share it below!

Seriously, donâ€™t leave me hanging as the only one with this kind of experience? ğŸ™

ğŸ›¡ï¸ This was not a solo quest â€”

ChatGPT tagged along for the ride ğŸ¤–ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»

Every Wednesday morning(ish), expect a new post diving into my current favorite topic: GitHub Copilot. You can expect the useful, the weird, the frustrating, the dramatic â€” and everything in between. That could be lunchtime in London, dinnertime in Delhi, or â€œoops I overslept (again)â€ on the East Coast. â°

ğŸŒªï¸ 2. Surprise Posts (Like This)

The rest? Unfiltered, unscheduled, mildly chaotic, and completely unpredictable â€œthought dumpsâ€ that donâ€™t fit neatly into a Copilot post. Even I don't know when a moment will strike! Like this one (and the other few random thoughts in my ChatGPT that are sure to follow soon).

So that's my "un-officially official" plan â€” no backing out now. But honestly... I've been having a blast! Yâ€™all are awesome, and I couldnâ€™t have found a better group of people to share, chat, and learn with. ğŸ’•

This post is a direct response to four nearly identical articles by @abhi_jith_f00c2ff58ac2a7e, all titled â€œThe Dark Side of AI: How ChatGPT Can Lead to Psychosis and Mental Health Concerns,â€ published today (July 20, 2025):
1 â€¢ 2 â€¢ 3 â€¢ 4

Iâ€™ve reported these posts, though Iâ€™m not exactly expecting much discourse against an account ending in â€œf00c2ff58ac2a7e.â€ Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m sharing my response here as a standalone post, in addition to my comments. What follows is nearly identical to my replies to those posts - plus a quick summary of the original articles (so you donâ€™t need to click and give them extra views; trust me, youâ€™re not missing anything) - along with my own perspective, so you know just how strongly I feel about this issue.

Please feel free to copy, share, and amplify. Letâ€™s work together to push back against this kind of fear-mongering and make it clear to every person - young or old: mental health struggles are never your fault.

First, a PSA for anyone who needs it:

If you or someone you know is experiencing a mental health crisis in the U.S., you can call 988 anytime, day or night, for free support. 988 is for any topic, offers support in English and Spanish (interpreters for other languages), and lets you talk, text, chat online, or use VP. Thereâ€™s even a dedicated Teen & Young Adult Helpline (#TalktoUs) with peer support - again, all free and confidential.

If youâ€™re outside the U.S., HelpGuide.org lists helplines for several other countries, including the UK, South Africa, New Zealand, Philippines, Ireland, Australia, Canada, and India. Itâ€™s not global (yet), but itâ€™s a start.

Itâ€™s critical to recognize warning signs for early mental health crisis intervention and know how to support someone who might be experiencing first-episode psychosis (often seen in teens and young adults prior to a diagnosis of schizophrenia). Hallucinations and delusions are well-known symptoms, but early signs can also look like depression. Thereâ€™s no cure, but schizophrenia and related disorders are very treatable - and treatment today usually means medication and counseling, not hospitals or â€œscaryâ€ interventions. Some helpful resources:

  • SAMHSA: Schizophrenia
  • Mayo Clinic
  • NAMI: About Schizophrenia
  • NIMH: Statistics
  • NAMI: The Michael Laudor Tragedy

Now, to the posts

The central claim of these posts is that the rapid adoption and widespread, frequent use of AI - particularly chatbots like ChatGPT - is responsible for what the author describes as a rise in mental health disorders among teens and young adults. While the term â€œpsychosisâ€ is used (rather than â€œschizophreniaâ€), the narrative strongly implies a direct cause-and-effect relationship that simply isnâ€™t supported by research.

The author includes an anecdote about a young person who used ChatGPT as a sort of â€œfriend,â€ supposedly leading them to blur the lines between technology and reality.

My Biggest Problem with This

This conversation is so important - but letâ€™s clear something up: blaming AI (or any single thing) for youth mental health or psychosis isnâ€™t just misleading; itâ€™s flat-out unhelpful.

Even if we take the story at face value (thereâ€™s no supporting evidence or sources provided, so thatâ€™s a big if), it is absolutely NOT their fault!

The mere suggestion that a serious, life-altering condition like psychosis could be caused by something a person - young or old - did or didnâ€™t do is not just incorrect and unhelpful, itâ€™s dangerous.

This kind of thinking is exactly why so many people are hesitant to seek help: they feel like itâ€™s something they â€œbrought on themselvesâ€ or could have prevented. The truth is, itâ€™s not anyoneâ€™s fault - least of all your own.

The Truth about Psychosis

Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders typically first appear in teens and young adults, but thatâ€™s not because of the latest tech trend.

To quote NAMI:

â€œ50% of all lifetime mental illness begins by age 14, and 75% by age 24.â€

title: âš™ï¸ Build It Better: Real-World AI Coding with GitHub Copilot
content_html:
Originally shared as an internal how-to document.

GitHub Copilot as a true pair programmer

I've spent a lot of time testing workflows, instructions and prompts. Some with more context, some with less. I've gotten some great results and some spectacular failures! Here's an overview of what I found works for nearly every scenario when using GitHub Copilot Agent mode as a pair implementation specialist.

ğŸ“Œ TL;DR

  1. Set up repo-level instructions & starter template
  2. Know your goal & break tasks into stories
  3. Explore options in Ask mode for planning
  4. Design a comprehensive, context-rich prompt
  5. Spell out rules, conventions & self-review steps
  6. Choose the right AI model for each task
  7. Require a self-review pass
  8. Supervise your AI pairâ€”pause & redirect
  9. Review & refine changes like a seasoned engineer
  10. Provide feedback, reprompt & repeat

1. Set Up Repo-Level Instructions

Why it matters: Repo instructions give Copilot the context it needs before any new code exists. This is your baseline and everything from here on will depend on this.

ğŸ” If you missed it, check out my previous post All Iâ€™ve Learned About GitHub Copilot Instructions (So Far).

If you're starting a brand new project, use a starter template to scaffold basic structure and create a minimum set of instructions that includes:

Category Description Notes
Project Overview What does this repo do? Why does it matter?
Testing Requirements TDD strategy, code coverage %, test types, error handling, edge cases. I never had a great opportunity to test Copilot's reaction to TDD. Add your experience below!
Documentation Javadoc, README, Swagger/OpenAPI specs. âœ¨ If you want something a little more advanced, look into mermaid diagrams!
Design & Security Architecture constraints, naming conventions, auth rules.
Review Rules Checklist for self-reviews and criteria for acceptance. This step will save you a ton of time in the long run.

2. Know Your Goal & Break It Down

âœ¨ Side-project vibe-code?
ğŸ› ï¸ Production bug fix?
ğŸŒ€ Somewhere in between?

Define your end goal, then split work into small, targeted stories that Copilot can handle one step at a time. If a task can be broken down further, do so - youâ€™ll get better results. The smaller and more targeted you define the task, the better results youâ€™ll get in the end.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: Give Copilot access to your issue tracker via an MCP server. That's one less thing to copy/paste and you can add an update clause in your prompt to let Copilot handle the comments and even issue tracking status or labels directly.

3. Explore in Ask Mode

If you know exactly how, why, and where, then you can probably skip this step. Otherwise, before coding, do a little exploring with Copilot Ask mode. Prompt it with something like:

Given requirements in JIRA-123, analyze #codebase and propose 3 implementation options with pros/cons. Score each by simplicity & maintainability. Recommend one.

Iterate until uncertainties are surfaced and addressed. This is also the perfect time to validate your setup, including the story itself and custom instructions. Ask yourself, is the result what you expected it to be? If not, can you pinpoint which detail was unclear or too complex?

This is not only a great time to improve your custom instructions and story definition, but also explore alternative approaches. You might even think of something you wouldn't have otherwise.

âš ï¸ Be careful with overconfident models. Sometimes you will read an explanation presented with such a high degree of certainty that youâ€™ll catch yourself agreeing with it regardless of whether it actually makes sense for your use case.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: Ask mode is perfect for exploration. It prevents Copilot from making changes to the code before youâ€™re ready and it saves a premium request.

4. Design a Comprehensive Prompt

Consider how you want to prompt Copilot to complete its task. For a high-impact production fix, you will probably want to keep a tight leash on the exact implementation. The more straightforward the prompt and instructions are, the less room Copilot has to veer off its intended path or hallucinate a better implementation than the one you had planned.

Your prompt should include:

  1. Specific #file or #selection that is relevant to the task
  2. Open any related or secondary files in the editor as additional context
  3. A numbered list of implementation steps, if you need better control or visibility along the way.
  4. Specify any important design patterns, security concerns, or future work planned (can also be separate .github/instructions/specific-guidelines.instruction.md files in the repo for ultimate reusability.
  5. Identify any important config files (like ./eslint.config.js or ./vitest.config.js) that Copilot must adhere to and put them in context with #file.
  6. For complex tasks, add an extra step instructing Copilot to consider at least X alternative approaches before starting work. Assess whether the detailed implementation plan covers all edge cases and error scenarios appropriately. If not, then update accordingly before moving on.

It's always better to be more specific and more strict than to provide no guidance at all. If that means your prompt is closer to the size of a 3-page essay, then that's OK! Try it out and make changes later, if needed.

â€¼ï¸ Example prompt: 

Assess this #codebase in conjunction with the #file:README.md. Use #githubRepo tool to reference other codebases, as needed. 
Without making any changes to the existing code, generate a new PROJECT_DIAGRAM.md file that correctly illustrates a mermaid diagram for this repository. 
Adhere to the following guidelines:
1. The primary project diagram should be a very high-level and only include inputs, major functionality/business logic/outputs. 
   If it links to a separate project, those should be well documented.
2. For each primary use case you can identify, generate a diagram for it that includes enough detail to document the process end to end, 
   but leave out any irrelevant processing or "common sense" logic. 
3. Every diagram should have its own section that includes the mermaid diagram itself, a brief description of its purpose, 
   any external factors or links, troubleshooting steps for common failures, and suggested future improvements,
   if any exist, that would improve maintainability or eliminate potential bugs.
4. Ensure this new project_diagram is linked to from the primary #file:README.md

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: Mermaid diagrams are a great addition to any README.md and GitHub renders them without any help on your end. If you want the preview to display in VS Code, you'll need to install an extension. I use bierner.markdown-mermaid but there's a ton of them available.

5. Spell Out Rules & Guidelines

Reference your README.md or .github/custom-instructions.md file when defining strict guidelines, especially if a commit hook or linter is involved.

In your prompt, try adding something similar to:

Follow conventions in README.md: Javadoc, pass all tests, adhere to secure coding guidelines.

For narrow tasks, add file-specific context:

Implement within #MyComponent.tsx, preserve API interface.

ğŸ¹ One prompt â†’ one premium request in Agent Mode. Maximize your premium usage by combining as much information and context into a single prompt as possible.

6. Choose the Right AI Model

The model you choose is probably the next biggest impact to the overall implementation and outcome. When in doubt, try the cheapest one first (aka smallest premium multiplier). If it doesn't work the first time, /clear everything and then re-submit the prompt.

Task Recommended Model Alternate Model
New feature or complex logic Claude Sonnet (any version) Claude Opus
Quick fix o3/4-mini Gemini 2.0 Flash
Heavy analysis or debugging o3/4 (regular) Gemini 2.5 Pro
Ideation or creative exploration GPT-4.1 GPT-4.5

ğŸ“Œ Refer to GitHub's model cheatsheet for more detailed info about picking the right model.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: The VS Code Chat extension works like your terminal - just press the up arrow key to rotate through previous chats, even after you've cleared them. You can also use the history button at the top to return to a previously cleared chat.

7. Require a Self-Review Pass

Either in the overall initial prompt or in a custom-instructions file, instruct GitHub Copilot to complete a detailed self-review of all changes made according to a set guideline (security, optimization, maintainability, etc):

- Pass all tests & coverage checks
- Meet lint & format requirements
- Perform a detailed self-review with a focus on secure coding practices

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: You'll save on premium requests if you include the self-review requirements in the initial prompt. However, you'll get better results if you separate the review step from the implementation (be sure to /clear and consider changing the model, too!)

title: ğŸ§  Letting AI Drive: A Month of Building with GitHub Copilot
content_html:
â€œWhen the going gets weird, the weird turn pro.â€

â€” Hunter S. Thompson

What happens when you stop writing code and start managing your AI developer instead?

âš¡ TL;DR;

I gave GitHub Copilot full control of a built-from-scratch NodeJS project for a month.

ChatGPT handled planning, strategy, UX input, and story writing.

I acted as manager, director, and chaos wrangler.

The result:

A working prototype, repeatable prompt patterns, and serious lessons on using AI as your dev partner.

ğŸ‘‹ Setup

Built as a personal experiment on a work machine (private, for now).

Toolchain:

  • VS Code Insiders, started in Codespaces for safety
  • Full access granted to terminal, extensions, file tree, everything
  • Linting + formatting: ESLint, Prettier, Remark, Commitlint (strictly enforced)
  • Testing: Vitest with 90%+ coverage enforcement
  • Copilot handled: Code, tests, docs, commit messages, pull requests, story implementation
  • ChatGPT handled: Story writing, backlog creation, research, branding
  • Workflow: Start with instructions (repo-level + personal) â†’ evolve into structured prompts â†’ iterate and commit

Most //human input lines were documentation. Actual code edits? Maybe two â€” one for manual testing and one was copy/pasted.

ğŸ§ª How I Actually Prompt (GitHub Copilot)

ğŸ§  Copilot Agent Settings

Note: By default, Ask mode doesn't save historical context

Depending on what Iâ€™m doing, I pick a specific model under Agent mode:

  • ğŸ› ï¸ Feature implementation, heavy refactor, full Aâ†’Q problem-solving

    • Claude Sonnet 4 or Claude Sonnet 3.7

  • ğŸ§ª Testing, docs, explanation, general idea bouncing

    • GPT-4.1 or GPT-4o

  • ğŸ” Somewhere in between

    • Gemini 2.5 Pro (when it actually works)

  • âš™ï¸ Light scripting, config setup, follow-along patterns

    • o4-mini

ğŸ§· Most-Used Contexts

  • #terminalLastCommand
  • #selection
  • #file

ğŸ§  My Go-To Prompts

When Iâ€™m Stuck 

#codebase I want to build a <thing> for <goal>.  
Given current best practices in <language>, analyze the top 3 ways to implement it. 
List 2 pros/cons for each. 
Rate 1â€“5 for complexity, ease of use, maintainability. 
Rank them and explain why.

Even when the simplest ones didnâ€™t work right away, they always got the ball rolling. If needed, I clarified or reset with /clear and tried again.

Doesn't Compile 

/fix #the-file-copilot-prob-broke-anyway.js

Failing Tests 

/fix #terminalLastCommand

Lint errors 

/fix #problems

â˜ ï¸ The Copilot Hell Loop Is Real

It happens: Copilot spirals into broken logic and keeps rewriting working code.

Hereâ€™s what works:

Pause â†’ Redirect â†’ Resume

(But donâ€™t wait too long â€” or your fix becomes git reset --hard HEAD.)

ğŸ“š What I Learned

âœ… Models Matter

Pick the right one â€” it'll save you hours of rework.

âœ… Specific Prompts Win

Copilot thrives on intent and clarity, not vague instructions.

âœ… Back-and-Forth Works

#selection I was thinking of doing X here â€” would you recommend that?

Copilot actually responds meaningfully.

âœ… Commit While It Works

Donâ€™t wait for perfect. Save progress, iterate fast.

âœ… No Plan? No Problem (Sometimes)

Just stay curious and let your Copilot riff with you.

âŒ #codebase for Direct Implementation Doesn't Work (for Me)

I know it's a headline feature, but asking Copilot to /implement-feature JIRA-123 #codebase has never worked well for me.

What does work? Asking targeted questions, especially during active review or when youâ€™re trying to break down next steps.

âš ï¸ Long-Running Chat Histories Hit a Wall

Even if you think building a giant rolling context will help, Copilot's memory eventually falls off.

What worked better:

Story â†’ review â†’ refine â†’ commit â†’ /clear

Repeat that and results stayed sharp.

ğŸ¤ Try It: VS Code Speech for Conversational Prompts

VS Code Speech gives you a â€œhey code!â€ style interaction with Copilot.

You can speak out goals, requests, or reviews and let it translate to code suggestions.

âš ï¸ Just watch your token usage â€” premium-style interactions can balloon into fast rate limits if you're not careful.

âœ… ChatGPT = Worth the subscription

Docs, strategies, structure, creative writing, even â€œHey, does this make sense?â€ moments.

We can't always live in code (plus, who can resist playing with pictures and color?)

Yes, it helped with this post too!

âœ¨ Letâ€™s Talk

Questions? Want to swap prompts, patterns, or war stories? Hit me up â€” just give me a few weeks to recover.

Iâ€™m still prepping for the internal demo and approvals.

This was Part 1 of a 2-part breakdown.

Next up: The build, the metrics, and what 600,000+ lines of AI-generated code actually look like in the wild. Letting AI Drive: From Hell Loops to Happy Commits.

ğŸ›¡ï¸ RAI Disclaimer

Everything I share here is my own perspectiveâ€”created with the help of AI tools (GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT, and their friends), but always with a human in the loop. I do my best to catch accidental bias and fact-check, but if you ever spot something odd, let me know! AI isnâ€™t perfect, and neither am I.

TL; DR: AI helped, but you can blame me for the chaos! ğŸ«
